pollution. Effective management ensures the sustainable use of water, balancing human needs with environmental protection. Here&#x27;s an overview of the global context and the relevance of the water bottling industry:\n\n### Global Context of Water Resources Management\n\n1. **Water Scarcity and Stress**:\n   - Over 2 billion people live in countries experiencing high water stress.\n   - Climate change exacerbates water scarcity by altering precipitation patterns and increasing the frequency of extreme weather events.\n\n2. **Population Growth**:\n   - The global population is projected to reach nearly 10 billion by 2050, increasing the demand for water for domestic, agricultural, and industrial use.\n\n3. **Agricultural Demand**:\n   - Agriculture accounts for about 70% of global freshwater withdrawals, making efficient water use in this sector crucial for food security and sustainability.\n\n4. **Pollution and Quality**:\n   - Industrial discharge, agricultural runoff, and inadequate wastewater treatment contribute to water pollution, affecting both human health and ecosystems.\n\n5. **Transboundary Water Management**:\n   - Many water bodies cross national borders, requiring cooperation between countries to manage shared resources sustainably.\n\n### Relevance of the Water Bottling Industry\n\n1. **Market Growth**:\n   - The bottled water industry has seen significant growth, driven by concerns about water quality, convenience, and health.\n\n2. **Economic Impact**:\n   - The industry provides jobs and economic benefits in regions with bottling plants and contributes to local economies through sales and distribution networks.\n\n3. **Environmental Concerns**:\n   - The production and disposal of plastic bottles contribute to environmental pollution. The industry faces criticism for its role in plastic waste and its carbon footprint from production and transportation.\n\n4. **Resource Extraction**:\n   - Bottling companies often extract large quantities of groundwater, which can lead to depletion of local water resources and impact communities and ecosystems.\n\n5. **Regulatory and Sustainability Efforts**:\n   - There is increasing pressure on the water bottling industry to adopt sustainable practices, including improved water management, reduction of plastic use, and enhanced recycling efforts.\n\n### Conclusion\n\nEffective water resources management is essential to address global challenges such as water scarcity, pollution, and climate change. The water bottling industry, while economically significant, must navigate environmental and social concerns to ensure sustainable and equitable access to water resources."]}, "status": "finished_successfully","end_turn": true

\u3010327\u2020Espa\u00f1ol\u2020www.bancomundial.org\u3011 \n  * \u3010328\u2020\u0627\u0644\u0639\u0631\u0628\u064a\u0629\u2020www.albankaldawli.org\u3011 \n  * \u3010329\u2020Fran\u00e7ais\u2020www.banquemondiale.org\u3011 \n\n[Image 6: The World Bank] \n\n# WATER RESOURCES MANAGEMENT\n\nWater scarcity affects more than 40% of the global population. Water-related disasters account for 70% of all deaths related to natural disasters. The World Bank helps countries ensure sustainability of water use, build climate resilience and strengthen integrated management.\n\n  * Context &amp; Challenges\n  * Strategy\n  * Results &amp; Initiatives\n\nToday, most countries are placing unprecedented pressure on water resources. The global population is growing fast, and estimates show that with current practices, the world will face a 40% shortfall between forecast demand and available supply of water by 2030. Furthermore, chronic water scarcity, hydrological uncertainty, and extreme weather events (floods and droughts) are perceived as some of the biggest threats to global prosperity and stability. Acknowledgment of the role that water scarcity and drought are playing in aggravating fragility and conflict is increasing.\n\n\u3010330\u2020 \u3011\n\n\u3010330\u2020 \u3011\n\n\u3010330\u2020View the Full Infographic&gt;&gt;\u3011\n\nFeeding \u3010331\u202010 billion people by 2050 will require a 50% increase in agricultural production\u2020www.unwater.org\u3011, (which consumes 70% of the resource today), and a 15%\u00a0increase in water withdrawals. Besides this increasing demand, the resource is already scarce in many parts of the world. Estimates indicate that over 40% of the world population live in water scarce areas, and approximately \u00bc of world\u2019s GDP is exposed to this challenge. \u3010332\u2020By 2040, an estimated one in four children will live in areas with extreme water shortages\u2020mcas-proxyweb.mcas.ms\u3011.\u00a0Water security is a major \u2013 and often growing \u2013challenge for many countries today.\n\nClimate change will worsen the situation by altering hydrological cycles, making water more unpredictable and increasing the frequency and intensity of floods and droughts. The roughly 1 billion people living in monsoonal basins and the 500 million people living in deltas are especially vulnerable.\u00a0 Flood damages are estimated around $120 billion per year (only from property damage), and droughts pose, among others, constraints to the rural poor, highly dependent on rainfall variability for subsistence.\u00a0\n\nThe fragmentation of this resource also constrains water security. There are 276 transboundary basins, shared by 148 countries, which account for 60% of the global freshwater flow. Similarly, 300 aquifers systems are transboundary in nature, with 2.5 billion people worldwide are dependent on groundwater. The challenges of fragmentation are often replicated at the national scale, meaning cooperation is needed to achieve optimal water resources management and development solutions for all riparians. To deal with these complex and interlinked water challenges, countries will need to improve the way they manage their water resources and associated services.\n\nTo strengthen water security against this backdrop of increasing demand, water scarcity, growing uncertainty, greater extremes, and fragmentation challenges, clients will need to invest in institutional strengthening, information management, and (natural and man-made) infrastructure development. Institutional tools such as legal and regulatory frameworks, water pricing, and incentives are needed to better allocate, regulate, and conserve water resources. Water-related disasters account for 70% of all deaths related to natural disasters. The World Bank helps countries ensure sustainability of water use, build climate resilience and strengthen integrated management.\n\n  * Context &amp; Challenges\n  * Strategy\n  * Results &amp; Initiatives\n\nToday, most countries are placing unprecedented pressure on water resources. The global population is growing fast, and estimates show that with current practices, the world will face a 40% shortfall between forecast demand and available supply of water by 2030. Furthermore, chronic water scarcity, hydrological uncertainty, and extreme weather events (floods and droughts) are perceived as some of the biggest threats to global prosperity and stability. Acknowledgment of the role that water scarcity and drought are playing in aggravating fragility and conflict is increasing.\n\n\u3010330\u2020 \u3011\n\n\u3010330\u2020 \u3011\n\n\u3010330\u2020View the Full Infographic&gt;&gt;\u3011\n\nFeeding \u3010331\u202010 billion people by 2050 will require a 50% increase in agricultural production\u2020www.unwater.org\u3011, (which consumes 70% of the resource today), and a 15%\u00a0increase in water withdrawals. Besides this increasing demand, the resource is already scarce in many parts of the world. Estimates indicate that over 40% of the world population live in water scarce areas, and approximately \u00bc of world\u2019s GDP is exposed to this challenge. \u3010332\u2020By 2040, an estimated one in four children will live in areas with extreme water shortages\u2020mcas-proxyweb.mcas.ms\u3011.\u00a0Water security is a major \u2013 and often growing \u2013challenge for many countries today.\n\nClimate change will worsen the situation by altering hydrological cycles, making water more unpredictable and increasing the frequency and intensity of floods and droughts. The roughly 1 billion people living in monsoonal basins and the 500 million people living in deltas are especially vulnerable.\u00a0 Flood damages are estimated around $120 billion per year (only from property damage), and droughts pose, among others, constraints to the rural poor, highly dependent on rainfall variability for subsistence.\u00a0\n\nThe fragmentation of this resource also constrains water security. There are 276 transboundary basins, shared by 148 countries, which account for 60% of the global freshwater flow. Similarly, 300 aquifers systems are transboundary in nature, with 2.5 billion people worldwide are dependent on groundwater. The challenges of fragmentation are often replicated at the national scale, meaning cooperation is needed to achieve optimal water resources management and development solutions for all riparians. To deal with these complex and interlinked water challenges, countries will need to improve the way they manage their water resources and associated services.\n\nTo strengthen water security against this backdrop of increasing demand, water scarcity, growing uncertainty, greater extremes, and fragmentation challenges, clients will need to invest in institutional strengthening, information management, and (natural and man-made) infrastructure development. Institutional tools such as legal and regulatory frameworks, water pricing, and incentives are needed to better allocate, regulate, and conserve water resources. Information systems are needed for resource monitoring, decision making under unce", "pub_date": null, "extra": null}], "original_query": null}, "command": "mclick", "args": ["[0, 1, 3, 4, 14]"], "status": "finished", "is_complete": true, "message_type": null, "model_slug": "gpt-4o", "default_model_slug": "gpt-4", "parent_id": "95a87f87-3134-4af4-9667-00306ddb7842", "request_id": "88b9a4daadea5a31-MXP", "timestamp_": "absolute"}, "recipient": "all", "channel": null}, "parent": "95a87f87-3134-4af4-9667-00306ddb7842", "children": ["6f1dca78-8aba-4215-91e8-975ea1632d4a"]}, "6f1dca78-8aba-4215-91e8-975ea1632d4a": {"id": "6f1dca78-8aba-4215-91e8-975ea1632d4a", "message": {"id": "6f1dca78-8aba-4215-91e8-975ea1632d4a", "author": {"role": "tool", "name": "browser", "metadata": {}}, "create_time": 1717018859.704981, "update_time": null, "content": {"content_type": "tether_quote", "url": "https://www.worldbank.org/en/topic/water/overview", "domain": "www.worldbank.org", "text": "\n#### \u00a0\n\n#### \u3010337\u2020 View the Dam Safety Infographic&gt;&gt;\u3011\n\n#### \u00a0\n\n#### \u3010338\u2020 View the Social Inclusion Infographic&gt;&gt;\u3011\n\n#### \u00a0\n\n#### \u3010339\u2020 View the Climate Change and Water Infographic&gt;&gt;\u3011\n\n#### \u00a0\n\n#### \u00a0\n\nLast Updated:\u00a0Jul 28, 2023\n\nIn response to the water and sanitation crisis, the World Bank Water Global Practice (Water GP) is\u00a0committed to Water for People and Planet. The SDGs provide an opportunity for the World Bank Group and development partners to work together in support of this vision.\n\nAnd, in 2019, the Water GP launched its new Strategic Action Plan. Our vision remains a Water Secure World for All, to be delivered through three inter-related pillars: (1)\u00a0sustain water resources, (2)\u00a0deliver services, and (3)\u00a0build resilience. The World Bank has played a key role in driving delivery when it comes to the SDGs. We continue to implement programs and projects across the world, convene a wide range of actors to achieve cross-sectoral solutions, and share our data, knowledge and know-how with others in service of a water-secure world for all.\n\nWith a portfolio of water investments of almost US$30 billion and a staff of hundreds of water experts across the world, the Water GP is uniquely positioned to address these themes, developing and sharing global knowledge while amplifying the impact of lending through technical assistance on the ground.\n\nThe World Bank has identified five priority themes to achieve the Sustainable Development Goal in the water sector (SDG 6). To address the challenges of increasing water scarcity and variability and to ensure that results are maintained in the future, a renewed focus on the multiple facets of resilience and sustainability is needed. However, without new efforts to improve inclusion, many will still be unable to reap the benefits of water and will be disproportionately impacted by water-related disasters.\n\nHelping countries achieve greater sustainability and inclusion in the water sector requires investment in institutions, to complement the traditional focus on building infrastructure. Building the institutions and infrastructure needed for universal access and more sustainable water management practices also demands a vast increase in financing for the water sector, which can only be achieved by improving financial viability and leveraging donor funding to tap other sources of finance.\n\nThese five priority themes form the core of a partnership for a water-secure world, supported by the \u3010340\u2020Global Water Security &amp; Sanitation Partnership (GWSP)\u3011. This is a Multi-Donor Trust Fund, launched in 2017 that enables the Water GP to address the five themes across its global portfolio.\n\nTo more effectively bring critical resources to the front lines, the GWSP has been designed as a Water GP core asset\u2014its \u201cthink-tank\u201d\u2014which expands and deepens the impact of its lending program.\n\nIn 2018, the \u3010341\u20202030 Water Resources Group (2030 WRG)\u2020www.2030wrg.org\u3011\u00a0\u2014 a public-private-civil society partnership \u2014 became part of the Water GP family. 2030 WRG supports government-accelerated reforms with the aim of ensuring sustainable water resources management for long-term development and economic growth.\n\nTo respond to COVID-19, action in the WASH sector is critical for both containing the virus and lowering its immediate impact and aftermath. Three priority areas are identified as part of the emergency response:\n\n  1. [Image 8: Medical]Safe WASH services in health care facilities (HCFs) to deliver quality health services; protect patients, health workers, and staff; and to prevent further transmission. The WASH in Health Care Facilities Global Baseline Report (JMP, 2019) highlighted that one in four HCFs lacks basic water service (affecting more than 900 million people), one in five HCFs has no sanitation service (affecting about 1.5 billion people), and one in six HCFs has no hygiene service. During an infectious disease outbreak, services should meet minimum quality standards and should be separated for infected vs. non-infected patients. Support should ensure services are not disrupted and products such as soap and alcohol-based hand rubs are available. These services should also be available in temporary HCFs and quarantine sites.\u00a0\n\n  2. [Image 9: Sign Language]Improving handwashing behavior, food hygiene, and safe water practices. Materials for handwashing and hygiene may include provision of fixed and portable handwashing facilities, purchase of soap and alcohol-based hand rubs, provision of water supplies for handwashing, and point of use water treatment. Schools, workplaces, markets, transport stations, and other areas where people gather all require easy access to handwashing facilities and water and soap for handwashing. Proven behavior change techniques can help increase the frequency and improve the practice of critical hygiene behaviors. Resources such as the\u00a0\u3010342\u2020Global Handwashing Partnership\u2020globalhandwashing.org\u3011\u00a0can be tapped to mobilize private, public, and civil society actors to support developing messaging and materials to respond to COVID-19 outbreaks in country.\u00a0\n\n  3. Emergency support to secure and extend water and sanitation service provision, including:\n\n  * [Image 10: Sink]Rapid and low-cost water service and sanitation provision for communities, health care facilities, and schools is critical to enable handwashing, hygiene, and disinfection. According to\u00a0\u3010343\u2020UN Habitat\u2020unhabitat.org\u3011, COVID-19 will hit the world\u2019s most vulnerable people the most, many of whom live in informal settlements and rural community settings. Providing quick, just-in-time community water access points/water kiosks (including provision of soap) in unserved urban and rural areas, and for unserved HCFs and schools is critical. This could include: (i) provision and operation of compact water treatment plants; (ii) construction and operation of water points and sanitation facilities to deliver water in strategic urban or rural points; and/or (iii) provis", "title": "Water Overview: Development news, research, data | World Bank", "tether_id": null}, "status": "finished_successfully", "end_turn": null, "weight": 0.0, "metadata": {"_cite_metadata": {"citation_format": {"name": "tether_og", "regex": "\u3010(\\d+)(?::(\\d+))?\u2020([^\u2020\u3010\u3011]*)[^\u3010\u3011]*?\u3011"}, "metadata_list": [{"type": "webpage", "title": "Water Overview: Development news, research, data | World Bank", "url": "https://www.worldbank.org/en/topic/water/overview", "text": "\n#### \u00a0\n\n#### \u3010337\u2020 View the Dam Safety Infographic&gt;&gt;\u3011\n\n#### \u00a0\n\n#### \u3010338\u2020 View the Social Inclusion Infographic&gt;&gt;\u3011\n\n#### \u00a0\n\n#### \u3010339\u2020 View the Climate Change and Water Infographic&gt;&gt;\u3011\n\n#### \u00a0\n\n#### \u00a0\n\nLast Updated:\u00a0Jul 28, 2023\n\nIn response to the water and sanitation crisis, the World Bank Water Global Practice (Water GP) is\u00a0committed to Water for People and Planet. The SDGs provide an opportunity for the World Bank Group and development partners to work together in support of this vision.\n\nAnd, in 2019, the Water GP launched its new Strategic Action Plan. Our vision remains a Water Secure World for All, to be delivered through three inter-related pillars: (1)\u00a0sustain water resources, (2)\u00a0deliver services, and (3)\u00a0build resilience. The World Bank has played a key role in driving delivery when it comes to the SDGs. We continue to implement programs and projects across the world, convene a wide range of actors to achieve cross-sectoral solutions, and share our data, knowledge and know-how with others in service of a water-secure world for all.\n\nWith a portfolio of water investments of almost US$30 billion and a staff of hundreds of water experts across the world, the Water GP is uniquely positioned to address these themes, developing and sharing global knowledge while amplifying the impact of lending through technical assistance on the ground.\n\nThe World Bank has identified five priority themes to achieve the Sustainable Development Goal in the water sector (SDG 6). To address the challenges of increasing water scarcity and variability and to ensure that results are maintained in the future, a renewed focus on the multiple facets of resilience and sustainability is needed. However, without new efforts to improve inclusion, many will still be unable to reap the benefits of water and will be disproportionately impacted by water-related disasters.\n\nHelping countries achieve greater sustainability and inclusion in the water sector requires investment in institutions, to complement the traditional focus on building infrastructure. Building the institutions and infrastructure needed for universal access and more sustainable water management practices also demands a vast increase in financing for the water sector, which can only be achieved by improving financial viability and leveraging donor funding to tap other sources of finance.\n\nThese five priority themes form the core of a partnership for a water-secure world, supported by the \u3010340\u2020Global Water Security &amp; Sanitation Partnership (GWSP)\u3011. This is a Multi-Donor Trust Fund, launched in 2017 that enables the Water GP to address the five themes across its global portfolio.\n\nTo more effectively bring critical resources to the front lines, the GWSP has been designed as a Water GP core asset\u2014its \u201cthink-tank\u201d\u2014which expands and deepens the impact of its lending program.\n\nIn 2018, the \u3010341\u20202030 Water Resources Group (2030 WRG)\u2020www.2030wrg.org\u3011\u00a0\u2014 a public-private-civil society partnership \u2014 became part of the Water GP family. 2030 WRG supports government-accelerated reforms with the aim of ensuring sustainable water resources management for long-term development and economic growth.\n\nTo respond to COVID-19, action in the WASH sector is critical for both containing the virus and lowering its immediate impact and aftermath. Three priority areas are identified as part of the emergency response:\n\n  1. [Image 8: Medical]Safe WASH services in health care facilities (HCFs) to deliver quality health services; protect patients, health workers, and staff; and to prevent further transmission. The WASH in Health Care Facilities Global Baseline Report (JMP, 2019) highlighted that one in four HCFs lacks basic water service (affecting more than 900 million people), one in five HCFs has no sanitation service (affecting about 1.5 billion people), and one in six HCFs has no hygiene service. During an infectious disease outbreak, services should meet minimum quality standards and should be separated for infected vs. non-infected patients. Support should ensure services are not disrupted and products such as soap and alcohol-based hand rubs are available. These services should also be available in temporary HCFs and quarantine sites.\u00a0\n\n  2. [Image 9: Sign Language]Improving handwashing behavior, food hygiene, and safe water practices. Materials for handwashing and hygiene may include provision of fixed and portable handwashing facilities, purchase of soap and alcohol-based hand rubs, provision of water supplies for handwashing, and point of use water treatment. Schools, workplaces, markets, transport stations, and other areas where people gather all require easy access to handwashing facilities and water and soap for handwashing. Proven behavior change techniques can help increase the frequency and improve the practice of critical hygiene behaviors. Resources such as the\u00a0\u3010342\u2020Global Handwashing Partnership\u2020globalhandwashing.org\u3011\u00a0can be tapped to mobilize private, public, and civil society actors to support developing messaging and materials to respond to COVID-19 outbreaks in country.\u00a0\n\n  3. Emergency support to secure and extend water and sanitation service provision, including:\n\n  * [Image 10: Sink]Rapid and low-cost water service and sanitation provision for communities, health care facilities, and schools is critical to enable handwashing, hygiene, and disinfection. According to\u00a0\u3010343\u2020UN Habitat\u2020unhabitat.org\u3011, COVID-19 will hit the world\u2019s most vulnerable people the most, many of whom live in informal settlements and rural community settings. Providing quick, just-in-time community water access points/water kiosks (including provision of soap) in unserved urban and rural areas, and for unserved HCFs and schools is critical. This could include: (i) provision and operation of compact water treatment plants; (ii) construction and operation of water points and sanitation facilities to deliver water in strategic urban or rural points; and/or (iii) provis", "pub_date": null, "extra": null}], "original_query": null}, "command": "mclick", "args": ["[0, 1, 3, 4, 14]"], "status": "finished", "is_complete": true, "message_type": null, "model_slug": "gpt-4o", "default_model_slug": "gpt-4", "parent_id": "d36dbc57-317e-4d0b-9d5c-b1a8126f18f1", "request_id": "88b9a4daadea5a31-MXP", "timestamp_": "absolute"}, "recipient": "all", "channel": null}, "parent": "d36dbc57-317e-4d0b-9d5c-b1a8126f18f1", "children": ["14894cb4-60f8-4662-89d8-179c1eab566d"]}, "14894cb4-60f8-4662-89d8-179c1eab566d": {"id": "14894cb4-60f8-4662-89d8-179c1eab566d", "message": {"id": "14894cb4-60f8-4662-89d8-179c1eab566d", "author": {"role": "tool", "name": "browser", "metadata": {}}, "create_time": 1717018859.705203, "update_time": null, "content": {"content_type": "tether_quote", "url": "https://datatopics.worldbank.org/sdgatlas/goal-6-clean-water-and-sanitation/", "domain": "datatopics.worldbank.org", "text": "\n# Water withdrawal has increased in many countries\n\n## Total freshwater withdrawal (billion m^{3}/year) and Total population\n\n[Image 8: Loading] \n\n\u301020\u2020Data\u3011 Image Copy Link\n\nSource: [link: http://fao.org/aquastat/statistics/query/index.html?lang=en FAO Aquastat database]. Retrieved from World Development Indicators ([link: https://data.worldbank.org/indicator/ER.H2O.FWTL.K3 ER.H2O.FWTL.K3], [link: https://data.worldbank.org/indicator/SP.POP.TOTL SP.POP.TOTL]).\n\nWater is essential to human needs, and a critical input to food production. Population growth naturally leads to more pressure on water resources, as illustrated by the correlation between population size and water withdrawals.\n\nWhile that correlation holds at the global level, there is significant variation from country to country.\n\nIn Uruguay for instance, water withdrawals have increased much faster than the population. This is partly explained by Uruguay\u2019s agricultural sector\u2019s specialization in water intensive products like beef, soybeans, and rice.\n\nIn contrast, owing to more efficient use of water resources, the United States has managed to withdraw less water over the same period of time, despite of a growing population.\n\nSource: [link: http://fao.org/aquastat/statistics/query/index.html?lang=en FAO Aquastat database]. Retrieved from World Development Indicators ([link: https://data.worldbank.org/indicator/ER.H2O.FWTL.K3 ER.H2O.FWTL.K3], [link: https://data.worldbank.org/indicator/SP.POP.TOTL SP.POP.TOTL]).\n\n* * *\n\nAround [emphasis: 70 percent] of global freshwater resources are used for [emphasis: agriculture].\n\n* * *\n\nIn low-income countries, water use in agriculture accounts for 90 percent of all water withdrawals. This is significantly less in high-income countries (44 percent), where a higher share of water goes to the industrial sector.\n\n# Agriculture is the main sector of water use\n\n## Water withdrawal by sector (% of total freshwater withdrawal) by income group, 2020\n\n[Image 9: Loading] \n\n\u301021\u2020Data\u3011 Image Copy Link\n\nSource: [link: http://fao.org/aquastat/statistics/query/index.html?lang=en FAO Aquastat database]. Retrieved from World Development Indicators ([link: https://data.worldbank.org/indicator/ER.H2O.FWTL.K3 ER.H2O.FWTL.K3], [link: https://data.worldbank.org/indicator/ER.H2O.FWAG.ZS ER.H2O.FWAG.ZS], [link: https://data.worldbank.org/indicator/ER.H2O.FWIN.ZS ER.H2O.FWIN.ZS], [link: https://data.worldbank.org/indicator/ER.H2O.FWDM.ZS ER.H2O.FWDM.ZS]).\n\nBetween 1960 and 2018, water withdrawals increased by 100 percent in agriculture, 90 percent in industry, and 300 percent in domestic use.[reference: UN-Water. 2021. [link: https://www.unwater.org/sites/default/files/app/uploads/2021/10/UN-Water-analytical-brief-Water-use-efficiency_October2021.pdf \u201cUN-Water Analytical Brief on Water Use Efficiency.\u201d] Geneva.] Although water use is becoming more efficient[reference: FAO (Food and Agriculture Organization). 2021. [link: https://www.fao.org/documents/card/en/c/cb6413en \u201cProgress on change in water-use efficiency: Global Status and Acceleration Needs for SDG Indicator 6.4.1.\u201d] Rome.] across all economic sectors, global demand for water is expected to keep increasing due to economic and population growth.[reference: WWAP (UNESCO World Water Assessment Programme). 2019. [link: https://unesdoc.unesco.org/ark:/48223/pf0000367306 \u201cWorld Water Development Report 2019: Leaving No One Behind.\u201d] Paris.] This growth is adding to pressure on water resources, while at the same time the water cycle is being impacted by climate change \u2013 two factors which may limit freshwater availability. It is therefore essential to monitor stress on water resources as an early warning indicator of potential scarcity.\n\n## Water stress: from global to local\n\n### Understanding water stress: What is water stress?\n\nThere are different ways of defining water stress.[footnote: Please see the following [link: https://www.mdpi.com/2073-4441/13/2/201 article.]] In this story, we will use the water stress indicator defined in SDG 6.4.2.[reference: United Nations Statistics Division. SDG Indicators Metadata repository. [link: https://unstats.un.org/sdgs/metadata/files/Metadata-06-04-02.pdf \u201cIndicator 6.4.2: Level of water stress - Definition and methodology\u201d].] The water stress indicator seeks to estimate the amount of pressure on a country\u2019s renewable freshwater resources.[footnote: The indicator for water stress does not consider human-made increases in water supply (such as desalination), and ignores water withdrawals that are recycled and reused.] It is defined as the ratio of total freshwater withdrawals divided by the available renewable freshwater.\n\nThe closer a country gets to 100 percent, the more pressure it places on its water resources. In some cases, the value of 100 percent can even be exceeded. This happens when a country consumes water resources that are non-renewable. It is therefore essential to monitor stress on water resources as an early warning indicator of potential scarcity.\n\n## Water stress: from global to local\n\n### Understanding water stress: What is water stress?\n\nThere are different ways of defining water stress.[footnote: Please see the following [link: https://www.mdpi.com/2073-4441/13/2/201 article.]] In this story, we will use the water stress indicator defined in SDG 6.4.2.[reference: United Nations Statistics Division. SDG Indicators Metadata repository. [link: https://unstats.un.org/sdgs/metadata/files/Metadata-06-04-02.pdf \u201cIndicator 6.4.2: Level of water stress - Definition and methodology\u201d].] The water stress indicator seeks to estimate the amount of pressure on a country\u2019s renewable freshwater resources.[footnote: The indicator for water stress does not consider human-made increases in water supply (such as desalination), and ignores water withdrawals that are recycled and reused.] It is defined as the ratio of total freshwater withdrawals divided by the available renewable freshwater.\n\nThe closer a country gets to 100 percent, the more pressure it places on its water resources. Annual Meetings\u3011\n\n* * *\n\n    * \u3010326\u2020 Contacts &amp; Inquiries \u3011\n\n  * [Image 4: WB Live]\n\nglobal Search dropdown\n\n[Image 5: Search graphic]\n\nSearch\n\n    Search button\n\n  1. \u30105\u2020Understanding Poverty\u3011\n  2. \u301048\u2020Topics\u3011\n  3. \u3010327\u2020Water \u3011\n\npublication November 16, 2023\n\n# Global Water Security and Sanitation Partnership: Annual Report 2023\n\n  *  \n  * \u3010328\u2020 \u3011 \n  *  \n  *  \n  *  \n  *  Share more\n\nclose\n\n    * [Image 6: Image] linkedin\n    * [Image 7: Image] digg\n    * [Image 8: Image] renren\n    * [Image 9: Image] stumbleupon\n    * [Image 10: Image] delicious\n    * [Image 11: Image] sina\n\n* * *\n\n[Image 12: Cover image of the GWSP 2023 Annual Report] \n\n* * *\n\nThe world is not on track with meeting the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). As of 2022, 2.2 billion people lacked safely managed drinking water, 3.5 billion lacked access to safely managed sanitation, and 2 billion lacked access to basic hand hygiene facilities. Today, global investment needs in the water sector exceed $1.37 trillion. To meet SDG 6 by 2030, investments must increase sixfold from the current level. Scaling up water investments will result in healthier people and ecosystems, climate-resilient irrigation and drainage services for farmers and improved water storage. In fiscal year 2023, the World Bank saw increased demand from client countries for assistance in building effective and efficient institutions for delivery of water and sanitation services, achieving climate-resilient irrigation, and managing worsening flood and drought risks. GWSP provided support for designing and implementing projects that are sustainable and resilient as well as inclusive policy advice. Over the past year, GWSP informed more than $13.5 billion of World Bank projects. Below are some of the highlights from GWSP in 2023.\n\nDownload the 2023 Global Water and Sanitation Partnership Annual Report \u3010329\u2020here\u2020documents1.worldbank.org\u3011.\n\nKEY MESSAGES:\n\nWith billions of people at risk, the global water crisis demands accelerated action.\n\n  * In 2022, 2.2 billion people lacked safely managed drinking water, 3.5 billion lacked safely managed sanitation, and 2 billion lacked basic hygiene services.\n  * Unaddressed, the water crisis may result in global, national, and regional conflicts.\n  * Investing in water will result in healthier people, economies, and ecosystems.\n  * We must act quickly, collectively, and on a much larger scale if we are to meet the water-related SDGs by 2030.\n\nAs a center of excellence for water-related issues, we are well positioned to help countries accelerate action on water.\n\n  * GWSP is a platform for collaboration and support of the water-related SDGs. Data and research help us understand these challenges and set priorities, share knowledge of what works, and measure progress.\n\nData &amp; Research\n\n    * \u301046\u2020Open Data\u2020data.worldbank.org\u3011\n    * \u3010303\u2020By Country\u2020data.worldbank.org\u3011\n    * \u3010304\u2020By Indicator\u2020data.worldbank.org\u3011\n    * \u301045\u2020Research &amp; Publications\u3011\n\nDevelopment Topics\n\n    * \u301040\u2020Climate Change\u3011\n    * \u3010305\u2020Agriculture and Food\u3011\n    * \u3010306\u2020Fragility, Conflict, and Violence\u3011\n    * \u3010307\u2020Poverty\u3011\n    * \u3010308\u2020Debt\u3011\n    * \u3010309\u2020Education\u3011\n    * \u3010310\u2020Health\u3011\n    * \u3010311\u2020Energy\u3011\n    * \u301041\u2020Food Security\u3011\n    * \u301048\u2020All Development Topics\u3011\n\n* * *\n\n    Search button\n\n  * \u30106\u2020WORK WITH US\u3011 \n\nFor Job Seekers\n\n    * \u3010312\u2020Jobs\u3011\n    * \u3010313\u2020Programs &amp; Internships\u3011\n\nFor Partners\n\n    * \u301011\u2020Partners\u3011\n    * \u3010314\u2020Corporate and Private Foundations\u3011\n    * \u3010315\u2020Clients\u2020clientconnection.worldbank.org\u3011\n    * \u3010316\u2020Private Sector\u3011\n    * \u3010317\u2020Corporate Procurement \u3011\n    * \u3010318\u2020Civil Society\u3011\n    * \u3010319\u2020Consultations\u2020consultations.worldbank.org\u3011\n    * \u3010320\u2020Parliamentarians\u3011\n\nFor Investors\n\n    * \u3010321\u2020World Bank Bonds &amp; Investment Products\u2020treasury.worldbank.org\u3011\n    * \u301052\u2020Treasury\u2020treasury.worldbank.org\u3011\n\nFor Learners\n\n    * \u301047\u2020Open Learning Campus\u2020olc.worldbank.org\u3011\n\nMeet Us\n\n    * \u3010322\u2020Events\u3011\n    * \u3010323\u2020World Bank Live\u2020live.worldbank.org\u3011\n    * \u3010324\u2020Speaker&#x27;s Bureau\u3011\n    * \u3010325\u2020Spring &amp; Annual Meetings\u3011\n\n* * *\n\n    * \u3010326\u2020 Contacts &amp; Inquiries \u3011\n\n  * [Image 4: WB Live]\n\nglobal Search dropdown\n\n[Image 5: Search graphic]\n\nSearch\n\n    Search button\n\n  1. \u30105\u2020Understanding Poverty\u3011\n  2. \u301048\u2020Topics\u3011\n  3. \u3010327\u2020Water \u3011\n\npublication November 16, 2023\n\n# Global Water Security and Sanitation Partnership: Annual Report 2023\n\n  *  \n  * \u3010328\u2020 \u3011 \n  *  \n  *  \n  *  \n  *  Share more\n\nclose\n\n    * [Image 6: Image] linkedin\n    * [Image 7: Image] digg\n    * [Image 8: Image] renren\n    * [Image 9: Image] stumbleupon\n    * [Image 10: Image] delicious\n    * [Image 11: Image] sina\n\n* * *\n\n[Image 12: Cover image of the GWSP 2023 Annual Report] \n\n* * *\n\nThe world is not on track with meeting the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). As of 2022, 2.2 billion people lacked safely managed drinking water, 3.5 billion lacked access to safely managed sanitation, and 2 billion lacked access to basic hand hygiene facilities. Today, global investment needs in the water sector exceed $1.37 trillion. To meet SDG 6 by 2030, investments must increase sixfold from the current level. Scaling up water investments will result in healthier people and ecosystems, climate-resilient irrigation and drainage services for farmers and improved water storage. In fiscal year 2023, the World Bank saw increased demand from client countries for assistance in building effective and efficient institutions for delivery of water and sanitation services, achieving climate-resilient irrigation, and managing worsening flood and drought risks. GWSP provided support for designing and implementing projects that are sustainable and resilient as well as inclusive policy advice. Over the past year, GWSP informed more than $13.5 billion of World Bank projects. Below are some of the highlights from GWSP in 2023.\n\nDownload the 2023 Global Water and Sanitation Partnership Annual Report \u3010329\u2020here\u2020documents1.worldbank.org\u3011.\n\nKEY MESSAGES:\n\nWith billions of people at risk, the global water crisis demands accelerated action.\n\n  * In 2022, 2.2 billion people lacked safely managed drinking water, 3.5 billion lacked safely managed sanitation, and 2 billion lacked basic hygiene services.\n  * Unaddressed, the water crisis may result in global, national, and regional conflicts.\n  * Investing in water will result in healthier people, economies, and ecosystems.\n  * We must act quickly, collectively, and on a much larger scale if we are to meet the water-related SDGs by 2030.\n\nAs a center of excellence for water-related issues, we are well positioned to help countries accelerate action on water.\n\n  * GWSP is a platform for collaboration and support of the water-related SDGs. We drive policy changes, b", "pub_date": null, "extra": null}], "original_query": null}, "command": "mclick", "args": ["[0, 1, 3, 4, 14]"], "status": "finished", "is_complete": true, "message_type": null, "model_slug": "gpt-4o", "default_model_slug": "gpt-4", "parent_id": "91ec5314-2d9d-461e-bdf8-083d63f6a843", "request_id": "88b9a4daadea5a31-MXP", "timestamp_": "absolute"}, "recipient": "all", "channel": null}, "parent": "91ec5314-2d9d-461e-bdf8-083d63f6a843", "children": ["66152320-b579-4527-b908-4404aa3d82f2"]}, "66152320-b579-4527-b908-4404aa3d82f2": {"id": "66152320-b579-4527-b908-4404aa3d82f2", "message": {"id": "66152320-b579-4527-b908-4404aa3d82f2", "author": {"role": "assistant", "name": null, "metadata": {}}, "create_time": 1717018859.705854, "update_time": null, "content": {"content_type": "text", "parts": ["### Global Context of Water Resources Management\n\n1. **Water Scarcity**:\n   - Over 40% of the global population is affected by water scarcity, a situation expected to worsen due to climate change and population growth. By 2030, the world could face a 40% shortfall between forecasted demand and available water supply\u30108\u2020source\u3011\u301010\u2020source\u3011.\n\n2. **Water Use**:\n   - Agriculture consumes 70% of global freshwater resources, with this percentage rising to 90% in low-income countries. Industrial and domestic uses account for the remaining water withdrawals\u301010\u2020source\u3011.\n   - Between 1960 and 2018, global water withdrawals increased by 100% in agriculture, 90% in industry, and 300% in domestic use\u301010\u2020source\u3011.\n\n3. **Impact of Climate Change**:\n   - Climate change is exacerbating water scarcity by altering hydrological cycles, leading to more frequent and intense floods and droughts. This affects approximately 1 billion people living in monsoonal basins and 500 million in deltas\u30108\u2020source\u3011.\n\n4. **Transboundary Water Management**:\n   - There are 276 transboundary river basins worldwide, shared by 148 countries, accounting for 60% of global freshwater flow. Effective management of these resources requires international cooperation\u30108\u2020source\u3011.\n\n### Relevance of the Water Bottling Industry\n\n1. **Economic Impact**:\n   - The bottled water industry is a significant economic sector, contributing to local economies through production, sales, and distribution. It provides numerous jobs and stimulates related industries\u30109\u2020source\u3011.\n\n2. **Environmental Concerns**:\n   - The industry faces criticism for its environmental impact, particularly regarding plastic waste and the carbon footprint associated with production and transportation. Efforts are underway to promote sustainable practices, including recycling and reducing plastic use\u30109\u2020source\u3011.\n\n3. **Water Extraction**:\n   - Bottling companies often extract large quantities of groundwater, which can lead to the depletion of local water resources, affecting communities and ecosystems\u30109\u2020source\u3011.\n\n4. **Regulation and Sustainability**:\n   - Increasing regulatory pressures and consumer demand for sustainability are driving the industry towards more environmentally friendly practices. This includes adopting better water management techniques and investing in infrastructure to reduce the environmental impact\u30109\u2020source\u3011.\n\n### Key Statistics\n\n- **Population Affected by Water Issues**:\n  - 2.2 billion people lack access to safely managed drinking water.\n  - 3.5 billion people lack access to safely managed sanitation.\n  - 2 billion people lack basic hygiene services\u301012\u2020source\u3011.\n\n- **Economic Investments**:\n  - Global investment needs in the water sector exceed $1.37 trillion to meet the Sustainable Development Goals (SDG 6) by 2030. Current investment levels need to increase sixfold to achieve these goals\u301012\u2020source\u3011.\n\nFor more detailed data and reports, you can visit the [World Bank Water Resources Management](https://www.worldbank.org/en/topic/water) page and the [Global Water Security and Sanitation Partnership Annual Report 2023](https://www.worldbank.org/en/publication/gwsp-annual-report-2023)."]}, "status": "finished_successfully","end_turn": true
, "weight": 1.0, "metadata": {"citations": [{"start_ix": 317, "end_ix": 327, "citation_format_type": "tether_og", "metadata": {"type": "webpage", "title": "Water Resources Management Overview: Development news, research, data | World Bank", "url": "https://www.worldbank.org/en/topic/waterresourcesmanagement", "text": "    * \u3010303\u2020By Country\u2020data.worldbank.org\u3011\n    * \u3010304\u2020By Indicator\u2020data.worldbank.org\u3011\n    * \u301045\u2020Research &amp; Annual Meetings\u3011\n\n* * *\n\n    * \u3010326\u2020 Contacts &amp; Inquiries \u3011\n\n  * [Image 4: WB Live]\n\nglobal Search dropdown\n\n[Image 5: Search graphic]\n\nSearch\n\n    Search button\n\n  1. \u30105\u2020Understanding Poverty\u3011\n  2. \u301048\u2020Topics\u3011\n\nThis page in: \n\n English \n\n  * \u3010327\u2020Espa\u00f1ol\u2020www.bancomundial.org\u3011\n  * \u3010328\u2020\u0627\u0644\u0639\u0631\u0628\u064a\u0629\u2020www.albankaldawli.org\u3011\n  * \u3010329\u2020Fran\u00e7ais\u2020www.banquemondiale.org\u3011\n\nThis page in: English\n\n  * \u3010327\u2020Espa\u00f1ol\u2020www.bancomundial.org\u3011 \n  * \u3010328\u2020\u0627\u0644\u0639\u0631\u0628\u064a\u0629\u2020www.albankaldawli.org\u3011 \n  * \u3010329\u2020Fran\u00e7ais\u2020www.banquemondiale.org\u3011 \n\n[Image 6: The World Bank] \n\n# WATER RESOURCES MANAGEMENT\n\nWater scarcity affects more than 40% of the global population. Water-related disasters account for 70% of all deaths related to natural disasters. The World Bank helps countries ensure sustainability of water use, build climate resilience and strengthen integrated management.\n\n  * Context &amp; Challenges\n  * Strategy\n  * Results &amp; Initiatives\n\nToday, most countries are placing unprecedented pressure on water resources. The global population is growing fast, and estimates show that with current practices, the world will face a 40% shortfall between forecast demand and available supply of water by 2030. Furthermore, chronic water scarcity, hydrological uncertainty, and extreme weather events (floods and droughts) are perceived as some of the biggest threats to global prosperity and stability. Acknowledgment of the role that water scarcity and drought are playing in aggravating fragility and conflict is increasing.\n\n\u3010330\u2020 \u3011\n\n\u3010330\u2020 \u3011\n\n\u3010330\u2020View the Full Infographic&gt;&gt;\u3011\n\nFeeding \u3010331\u202010 billion people by 2050 will require a 50% increase in agricultural production\u2020www.unwater.org\u3011, (which consumes 70% of the resource today), and a 15%\u00a0increase in water withdrawals. Besides this increasing demand, the resource is already scarce in many parts of the world. Estimates indicate that over 40% of the world population live in water scarce areas, and approximately \u00bc of world\u2019s GDP is exposed to this challenge. \u3010332\u2020By 2040, an estimated one in four children will live in areas with extreme water shortages\u2020mcas-proxyweb.mcas.ms\u3011.\u00a0Water security is a major \u2013 and often growing \u2013challenge for many countries today.\n\nClimate change will worsen the situation by altering hydrological cycles, making water more unpredictable and increasing the frequency and intensity of floods and droughts. The roughly 1 billion people living in monsoonal basins and the 500 million people living in deltas are especially vulnerable.\u00a0 Flood damages are estimated around $120 billion per year (only from property damage), and droughts pose, among others, constraints to the rural poor, highly dependent on rainfall variability for subsistence.\u00a0\n\nThe fragmentation of this resource also constrains water security. There are 276 transboundary basins, shared by 148 countries, which account for 60% of the global freshwater flow. Similarly, 300 aquifers systems are transboundary in nature, with 2.5 billion people worldwide are dependent on groundwater. The challenges of fragmentation are often replicated at the national scale, meaning cooperation is needed to achieve optimal water resources management and development solutions for all riparians. To deal with these complex and interlinked water challenges, countries will need to improve the way they manage their water resources and associated services.\n\nTo strengthen water security against this backdrop of increasing demand, water scarcity, growing uncertainty, greater extremes, and fragmentation challenges, clients will need to invest in institutional strengthening, information management, and (natural and man-made) infrastructure development. Institutional tools such as legal and regulatory frameworks, water pricing, and incentives are needed to better allocate, regulate, and conserve water resources. Information systems are needed for resource monitoring, decision making under unce", "pub_date": null, "extra": {"cited_message_idx": 8, "search_result_idx": null, "evidence_text": "source"}}}, {"start_ix": 327, "end_ix": 338, "citation_format_type": "tether_og", "metadata": {"type": "webpage", "title": "Clean water &amp; sanitation | SDG 6: Clean water &amp; sanitation", "url": "https://datatopics.worldbank.org/sdgatlas/goal-6-clean-water-and-sanitation/", "text": "\n# Water withdrawal has increased in many countries\n\n## Total freshwater withdrawal (billion m^{3}/year) and Total population\n\n[Image 8: Loading] \n\n\u301020\u2020Data\u3011 Image Copy Link\n\nSource: [link: http://fao.org/aquastat/statistics/query/index.html?lang=en FAO Aquastat database]. Retrieved from World Development Indicators ([link: https://data.worldbank.org/indicator/ER.H2O.FWTL.K3 ER.H2O.FWTL.K3], [link: https://data.worldbank.org/indicator/SP.POP.TOTL SP.POP.TOTL]).\n\nWater is essential to human needs, and a critical input to food production. Population growth naturally leads to more pressure on water resources, as illustrated by the correlation between population size and water withdrawals.\n\nWhile that correlation holds at the global level, there is significant variation from country to country.\n\nIn Uruguay for instance, water withdrawals have increased much faster than the population. This is partly explained by Uruguay\u2019s agricultural sector\u2019s specialization in water intensive products like beef, soybeans, and rice.\n\nIn contrast, owing to more efficient use of water resources, the United States has managed to withdraw less water over the same period of time, despite of a growing population.\n\nSource: [link: http://fao.org/aquastat/statistics/query/index.html?lang=en FAO Aquastat database]. Retrieved from World Development Indicators ([link: https://data.worldbank.org/indicator/ER.H2O.FWTL.K3 ER.H2O.FWTL.K3], [link: https://data.worldbank.org/indicator/SP.POP.TOTL SP.POP.TOTL]).\n\n* * *\n\nAround [emphasis: 70 percent] of global freshwater resources are used for [emphasis: agriculture].\n\n* * *\n\nIn low-income countries, water use in agriculture accounts for 90 percent of all water withdrawals. This is significantly less in high-income countries (44 percent), where a higher share of water goes to the industrial sector.\n\n# Agriculture is the main sector of water use\n\n## Water withdrawal by sector (% of total freshwater withdrawal) by income group, 2020\n\n[Image 9: Loading] \n\n\u301021\u2020Data\u3011 Image Copy Link\n\nSource: [link: http://fao.org/aquastat/statistics/query/index.html?lang=en FAO Aquastat database]. Retrieved from World Development Indicators ([link: https://data.worldbank.org/indicator/ER.H2O.FWTL.K3 ER.H2O.FWTL.K3], [link: https://data.worldbank.org/indicator/ER.H2O.FWAG.ZS ER.H2O.FWAG.ZS], [link: https://data.worldbank.org/indicator/ER.H2O.FWIN.ZS ER.H2O.FWIN.ZS], [link: https://data.worldbank.org/indicator/ER.H2O.FWDM.ZS ER.H2O.FWDM.ZS]).\n\nBetween 1960 and 2018, water withdrawals increased by 100 percent in agriculture, 90 percent in industry, and 300 percent in domestic use.[reference: UN-Water. 2021. [link: https://www.unwater.org/sites/default/files/app/uploads/2021/10/UN-Water-analytical-brief-Water-use-efficiency_October2021.pdf \u201cUN-Water Analytical Brief on Water Use Efficiency.\u201d] Geneva.] Although water use is becoming more efficient[reference: FAO (Food and Agriculture Organization). 2021. [link: https://www.fao.org/documents/card/en/c/cb6413en \u201cProgress on change in water-use efficiency: Global Status and Acceleration Needs for SDG Indicator 6.4.1.\u201d] Rome.] across all economic sectors, global demand for water is expected to keep increasing due to economic and population growth.[reference: WWAP (UNESCO World Water Assessment Programme). 2019. [link: https://unesdoc.unesco.org/ark:/48223/pf0000367306 \u201cWorld Water Development Report 2019: Leaving No One Behind.\u201d] Paris.] This growth is adding to pressure on water resources, while at the same time the water cycle is being impacted by climate change \u2013 two factors which may limit freshwater availability. It is therefore essential to monitor stress on water resources as an early warning indicator of potential scarcity.\n\n## Water stress: from global to local\n\n### Understanding water stress: What is water stress?\n\nThere are different ways of defining water stress.[footnote: Please see the following [link: https://www.mdpi.com/2073-4441/13/2/201 article.]] In this story, we will use the water stress indicator defined in SDG 6.4.2.[reference: United Nations Statistics Division. SDG Indicators Metadata repository. [link: https://unstats.un.org/sdgs/metadata/files/Metadata-06-04-02.pdf \u201cIndicator 6.4.2: Level of water stress - Definition and methodology\u201d].] The water stress indicator seeks to estimate the amount of pressure on a country\u2019s renewable freshwater resources.[footnote: The indicator for water stress does not consider human-made increases in water supply (such as desalination), and ignores water withdrawals that are recycled and reused.] It is defined as the ratio of total freshwater withdrawals divided by the available renewable freshwater.\n\nThe closer a country gets to 100 percent, the more pressure it places on its water resources. In some cases, the value of 100 percent can even be exceeded. This happens when a country consumes water resources that are non-renewable. It is therefore essential to monitor stress on water resources as an early warning indicator of potential scarcity.\n\n## Water stress: from global to local\n\n### Understanding water stress: What is water stress?\n\nThere are different ways of defining water stress.[footnote: Please see the following [link: https://www.mdpi.com/2073-4441/13/2/201 article.]] In this story, we will use the water stress indicator defined in SDG 6.4.2.[reference: United Nations Statistics Division. SDG Indicators Metadata repository. [link: https://unstats.un.org/sdgs/metadata/files/Metadata-06-04-02.pdf \u201cIndicator 6.4.2: Level of water stress - Definition and methodology\u201d].] The water stress indicator seeks to estimate the amount of pressure on a country\u2019s renewable freshwater resources.[footnote: The indicator for water stress does not consider human-made increases in water supply (such as desalination), and ignores water withdrawals that are recycled and reused.] It is defined as the ratio of total freshwater withdrawals divided by the available renewable freshwater.\n\nThe closer a country gets to 100 percent, the more pressure it places on its water resources. In some cases, the value of 100 percent can even be exceeded. This happens when a country consumes water resources that are non-renewable. This is the ", "pub_date": null, "extra": {"cited_message_idx": 10, "search_result_idx": null, "evidence_text": "source"}}}, {"start_ix": 979, "end_ix": 989, "citation_format_type": "tether_og", "metadata": {"type": "webpage", "title": "Water Resources Management Overview: Development news, research, data | World Bank", "url": "https://www.worldbank.org/en/topic/waterresourcesmanagement", "text": "    * \u3010303\u2020By Country\u2020data.worldbank.org\u3011\n    * \u3010304\u2020By Indicator\u2020data.worldbank.org\u3011\n    * \u301045\u2020Research &amp; Publications\u3011\n\nDevelopment Topics\n\n    * \u301040\u2020Climate Change\u3011\n    * \u3010305\u2020Agriculture and Food\u3011\n    * \u3010306\u2020Fragility, Conflict, and Violence\u3011\n    * \u3010307\u2020Poverty\u3011\n    * \u3010308\u2020Debt\u3011\n    * \u3010309\u2020Education\u3011\n    * \u3010310\u2020Health\u3011\n    * \u3010311\u2020Energy\u3011\n    * \u301041\u2020Food Security\u3011\n    * \u301048\u2020All Development Topics\u3011\n\n* * *\n\n    Search button\n\n  * \u30106\u2020WORK WITH US\u3011 \n\nFor Job Seekers\n\n    * \u3010312\u2020Jobs\u3011\n    * \u3010313\u2020Programs &amp; Internships\u3011\n\nFor Partners\n\n    * \u301011\u2020Partners\u3011\n    * \u3010314\u2020Corporate and Private Foundations\u3011\n    * \u3010315\u2020Clients\u2020clientconnection.worldbank.org\u3011\n    * \u3010316\u2020Private Sector\u3011\n    * \u3010317\u2020Corporate Procurement \u3011\n    * \u3010318\u2020Civil Society\u3011\n    * \u3010319\u2020Consultations\u2020consultations.worldbank.org\u3011\n    * \u3010320\u2020Parliamentarians\u3011\n\nFor Investors\n\n    * \u3010321\u2020World Bank Bonds &amp; Annual Meetings\u3011\n\n* * *\n\n    * \u3010326\u2020 Contacts &amp; Inquiries \u3011\n\n  * [Image 4: WB Live]\n\nglobal Search dropdown\n\n[Image 5: Search graphic]\n\nSearch\n\n    Search button\n\n  1. \u30105\u2020Understanding Poverty\u3011\n  2. \u301048\u2020Topics\u3011\n\nThis page in: \n\n English \n\n  * \u3010327\u2020Espa\u00f1ol\u2020www.bancomundial.org\u3011\n  * \u3010328\u2020\u0627\u0644\u0639\u0631\u0628\u064a\u0629\u2020www.albankaldawli.org\u3011\n  * \u3010329\u2020Fran\u00e7ais\u2020www.banquemondiale.org\u3011\n\nThis page in: English\n\n  * \u3010327\u2020Espa\u00f1ol\u2020www.bancomundial.org\u3011 \n  * \u3010328\u2020\u0627\u0644\u0639\u0631\u0628\u064a\u0629\u2020www.albankaldawli.org\u3011 \n  * \u3010329\u2020Fran\u00e7ais\u2020www.banquemondiale.org\u3011 \n\n[Image 6: The World Bank] \n\n# WATER RESOURCES MANAGEMENT\n\nWater scarcity affects more than 40% of the global population. Water-related disasters account for 70% of all deaths related to natural disasters. The World Bank helps countries ensure sustainability of water use, build climate resilience and strengthen integrated management.\n\n  * Context &amp; Challenges\n  * Strategy\n  * Results &amp; Initiatives\n\nToday, most countries are placing unprecedented pressure on water resources. The global population is growing fast, and estimates show that with current practices, the world will face a 40% shortfall between forecast demand and available supply of water by 2030. Furthermore, chronic water scarcity, hydrological uncertainty, and extreme weather events (floods and droughts) are perceived as some of the biggest threats to global prosperity and stability. Acknowledgment of the role that water scarcity and drought are playing in aggravating fragility and conflict is increasing.\n\n\u3010330\u2020 \u3011\n\n\u3010330\u2020 \u3011\n\n\u3010330\u2020View the Full Infographic&gt;&gt;\u3011\n\nFeeding \u3010331\u202010 billion people by 2050 will require a 50% increase in agricultural production\u2020www.unwater.org\u3011, (which consumes 70% of the resource today), and a 15%\u00a0increase in water withdrawals. Besides this increasing demand, the resource is already scarce in many parts of the world. Estimates indicate that over 40% of the world population live in water scarce areas, and approximately \u00bc of world\u2019s GDP is exposed to this challenge. \u3010332\u2020By 2040, an estimated one in four children will live in areas with extreme water shortages\u2020mcas-proxyweb.mcas.ms\u3011.\u00a0Water security is a major \u2013 and often growing \u2013challenge for many countries today.\n\nClimate change will worsen the situation by altering hydrological cycles, making water more unpredictable and increasing the frequency and intensity of floods and droughts. The roughly 1 billion people living in monsoonal basins and the 500 million people living in deltas are especially vulnerable.\u00a0 Flood damages are estimated around $120 billion per year (only from property damage), and droughts pose, among others, constraints to the rural poor, highly dependent on rainfall variability for subsistence.\u00a0\n\nThe fragmentation of this resource also constrains water security. There are 276 transboundary basins, shared by 148 countries, which account for 60% of the global freshwater flow. Similarly, 300 aquifers systems are transboundary in nature, with 2.5 billion people worldwide are dependent on groundwater. The challenges of fragmentation are often replicated at the national scale, meaning cooperation is needed to achieve optimal water resources management and development solutions for all riparians. To deal with these complex and interlinked water challenges, countries will need to improve the way they manage their water resources and associated services.\n\nTo strengthen water security against this backdrop of increasing demand, water scarcity, growing uncertainty, greater extremes, and fragmentation challenges, clients will need to invest in institutional strengthening, information management, and (natural and man-made) infrastructure development. Institutional tools such as legal and regulatory frameworks, water pricing, and incentives are needed to better allocate, regulate, and conserve water resources. Information systems are needed for resource monitoring, decision making under unce", "pub_date": null, "extra": {"cited_message_idx": 8, "search_result_idx": null, "evidence_text": "source"}}}, {"start_ix": 1233, "end_ix": 1243, "citation_format_type": "tether_og", "metadata": {"type": "webpage", "title": "Water Resources Management Overview: Development news, research, data | World Bank", "url": "https://www.worldbank.org/en/topic/waterresourcesmanagement", "text": "    * \u3010303\u2020By Country\u2020data.worldbank.org\u3011\n    * \u3010304\u2020By Indicator\u2020data.worldbank.org\u3011\n    * \u301045\u2020Research &amp; Publications\u3011\n\nDevelopment Topics\n\n    * \u301040\u2020Climate Change\u3011\n    * \u3010305\u2020Agriculture and Food\u3011\n    * \u3010306\u2020Fragility, Conflict, and Violence\u3011\n    * \u3010307\u2020Poverty\u3011\n    * \u3010308\u2020Debt\u3011\n    * \u3010309\u2020Education\u3011\n    * \u3010310\u2020Health\u3011\n    * \u3010311\u2020Energy\u3011\n    * \u301041\u2020Food Security\u3011\n    * \u301048\u2020All Development Topics\u3011\n\n* * *\n\n    Search button\n\n  * \u30106\u2020WORK WITH US\u3011 \n\nFor Job Seekers\n\n    * \u3010312\u2020Jobs\u3011\n    * \u3010313\u2020Programs &amp; Water-related disasters account for 70% of all deaths related to natural disasters. The World Bank helps countries ensure sustainability of water use, build climate resilience and strengthen integrated management.\n\n  * Context &amp; Challenges\n  * Strategy\n  * Results &amp; Initiatives\n\nToday, most countries are placing unprecedented pressure on water resources. The global population is growing fast, and estimates show that with current practices, the world will face a 40% shortfall between forecast demand and available supply of water by 2030. Furthermore, chronic water scarcity, hydrological uncertainty, and extreme weather events (floods and droughts) are perceived as some of the biggest threats to global prosperity and stability. Acknowledgment of the role that water scarcity and drought are playing in aggravating fragility and conflict is increasing.\n\n\u3010330\u2020 \u3011\n\n\u3010330\u2020 \u3011\n\n\u3010330\u2020View the Full Infographic&gt;&gt;\u3011\n\nFeeding \u3010331\u202010 billion people by 2050 will require a 50% increase in agricultural production\u2020www.unwater.org\u3011, (which consumes 70% of the resource today), and a 15%\u00a0increase in water withdrawals. Besides this increasing demand, the resource is already scarce in many parts of the world. Estimates indicate that over 40% of the world population live in water scarce areas, and approximately \u00bc of world\u2019s GDP is exposed to this challenge. \u3010332\u2020By 2040, an estimated one in four children will live in areas with extreme water shortages\u2020mcas-proxyweb.mcas.ms\u3011.\u00a0Water security is a major \u2013 and often growing \u2013challenge for many countries today.\n\nClimate change will worsen the situation by altering hydrological cycles, making water more unpredictable and increasing the frequency and intensity of floods and droughts. The roughly 1 billion people living in monsoonal basins and the 500 million people living in deltas are especially vulnerable.\u00a0 Flood damages are estimated around $120 billion per year (only from property damage), and droughts pose, among others, constraints to the rural poor, highly dependent on rainfall variability for subsistence.\u00a0\n\nThe fragmentation of this resource also constrains water security. There are 276 transboundary basins, shared by 148 countries, which account for 60% of the global freshwater flow. Similarly, 300 aquifers systems are transboundary in nature, with 2.5 billion people worldwide are dependent on groundwater. The challenges of fragmentation are often replicated at the national scale, meaning cooperation is needed to achieve optimal water resources management and development solutions for all riparians. To deal with these complex and interlinked water challenges, countries will need to improve the way they manage their water resources and associated services.\n\nTo strengthen water security against this backdrop of increasing demand, water scarcity, growing uncertainty, greater extremes, and fragmentation challenges, clients will need to invest in institutional strengthening, information management, and (natural and man-made) infrastructure development. Institutional tools such as legal and regulatory frameworks, water pricing, and incentives are needed to better allocate, regulate, and conserve water resources. Information systems are needed for resource monitoring, decision making under unce", "pub_date": null, "extra": {"cited_message_idx": 8, "search_result_idx": null, "evidence_text": "source"}}}, {"start_ix": 1518, "end_ix": 1528, "citation_format_type": "tether_og", "metadata": {"type": "webpage", "title": "Water Overview: Development news, research, data | World Bank", "url": "https://www.worldbank.org/en/topic/water/overview", "text": "\n#### \u00a0\n\n#### \u3010337\u2020 View the Dam Safety Infographic&gt;&gt;\u3011\n\n#### \u00a0\n\n#### \u3010338\u2020 View the Social Inclusion Infographic&gt;&gt;\u3011\n\n#### \u00a0\n\n#### \u3010339\u2020 View the Climate Change and Water Infographic&gt;&gt;\u3011\n\n#### \u00a0\n\n#### \u00a0\n\nLast Updated:\u00a0Jul 28, 2023\n\nIn response to the water and sanitation crisis, the World Bank Water Global Practice (Water GP) is\u00a0committed to Water for People and Planet. The SDGs provide an opportunity for the World Bank Group and development partners to work together in support of this vision.\n\nAnd, in 2019, the Water GP launched its new Strategic Action Plan. Our vision remains a Water Secure World for All, to be delivered through three inter-related pillars: (1)\u00a0sustain water resources, (2)\u00a0deliver services, and (3)\u00a0build resilience. The World Bank has played a key role in driving delivery when it comes to the SDGs. We continue to implement programs and projects across the world, convene a wide range of actors to achieve cross-sectoral solutions, and share our data, knowledge and know-how with others in service of a water-secure world for all.\n\nWith a portfolio of water investments of almost US$30 billion and a staff of hundreds of water experts across the world, the Water GP is uniquely positioned to address these themes, developing and sharing global knowledge while amplifying the impact of lending through technical assistance on the ground.\n\nThe World Bank has identified five priority themes to achieve the Sustainable Development Goal in the water sector (SDG 6). To address the challenges of increasing water scarcity and variability and to ensure that results are maintained in the future, a renewed focus on the multiple facets of resilience and sustainability is needed. However, without new efforts to improve inclusion, many will still be unable to reap the benefits of water and will be disproportionately impacted by water-related disasters.\n\nHelping countries achieve greater sustainability and inclusion in the water sector requires investment in institutions, to complement the traditional focus on building infrastructure. Building the institutions and infrastructure needed for universal access and more sustainable water management practices also demands a vast increase in financing for the water sector, which can only be achieved by improving financial viability and leveraging donor funding to tap other sources of finance.\n\nThese five priority themes form the core of a partnership for a water-secure world, supported by the \u3010340\u2020Global Water Security &amp; Sanitation Partnership (GWSP)\u3011. This is a Multi-Donor Trust Fund, launched in 2017 that enables the Water GP to address the five themes across its global portfolio.\n\nTo more effectively bring critical resources to the front lines, the GWSP has been designed as a Water GP core asset\u2014its \u201cthink-tank\u201d\u2014which expands and deepens the impact of its lending program.\n\nIn 2018, the \u3010341\u20202030 Water Resources Group (2030 WRG)\u2020www.2030wrg.org\u3011\u00a0\u2014 a public-private-civil society partnership \u2014 became part of the Water GP family. 2030 WRG supports government-accelerated reforms with the aim of ensuring sustainable water resources management for long-term development and economic growth.\n\nTo respond to COVID-19, action in the WASH sector is critical for both containing the virus and lowering its immediate impact and aftermath. Three priority areas are identified as part of the emergency response:\n\n  1. [Image 8: Medical]Safe WASH services in health care facilities (HCFs) to deliver quality health services; protect patients, health workers, and staff; and to prevent further transmission. The WASH in Health Care Facilities Global Baseline Report (JMP, 2019) highlighted that one in four HCFs lacks basic water service (affecting more than 900 million people), one in five HCFs has no sanitation service (affecting about 1.5 billion people), and one in six HCFs has no hygiene service. During an infectious disease outbreak, services should meet minimum quality standards and should be separated for infected vs. non-infected patients. Support should ensure services are not disrupted and products such as soap and alcohol-based hand rubs are available. These services should also be available in temporary HCFs and quarantine sites.\u00a0\n\n  2. [Image 9: Sign Language]Improving handwashing behavior, food hygiene, and safe water practices. Materials for handwashing and hygiene may include provision of fixed and portable handwashing facilities, purchase of soap and alcohol-based hand rubs, provision of water supplies for handwashing, and point of use water treatment. Schools, workplaces, markets, transport stations, and other areas where people gather all require easy access to handwashing facilities and water and soap for handwashing. Proven behavior change techniques can help increase the frequency and improve the practice of critical hygiene behaviors. Resources such as the\u00a0\u3010342\u2020Global Handwashing Partnership\u2020globalhandwashing.org\u3011\u00a0can be tapped to mobilize private, public, and civil society actors to support developing messaging and materials to respond to COVID-19 outbreaks in country.\u00a0\n\n  3. Emergency support to secure and extend water and sanitation service provision, including:\n\n  * [Image 10: Sink]Rapid and low-cost water service and sanitation provision for communities, health care facilities, and schools is critical to enable handwashing, hygiene, and disinfection. According to\u00a0\u3010343\u2020UN Habitat\u2020unhabitat.org\u3011, COVID-19 will hit the world\u2019s most vulnerable people the most, many of whom live in informal settlements and rural community settings. Providing quick, just-in-time community water access points/water kiosks (including provision of soap) in unserved urban and rural areas, and for unserved HCFs and schools is critical. This could include: (i) provision and operation of compact water treatment plants; (ii) construction and operation of water points and sanitation facilities to deliver water in strategic urban or rural points; and/or (iii) provis", "pub_date": null, "extra": {"cited_message_idx": 9, "search_result_idx": null, "evidence_text": "source"}}}, {"start_ix": 1834, "end_ix": 1844, "citation_format_type": "tether_og", "metadata": {"type": "webpage", "title": "Water Overview: Development news, research, data | World Bank", "url": "https://www.worldbank.org/en/topic/water/overview", "text": "\n#### \u00a0\n\n#### \u3010337\u2020 View the Dam Safety Infographic&gt;&gt;\u3011\n\n#### \u00a0\n\n#### \u3010338\u2020 View the Social Inclusion Infographic&gt;&gt;\u3011\n\n#### \u00a0\n\n#### \u3010339\u2020 View the Climate Change and Water Infographic&gt;&gt;\u3011\n\n#### \u00a0\n\n#### \u00a0\n\nLast Updated:\u00a0Jul 28, 2023\n\nIn response to the water and sanitation crisis, the World Bank Water Global Practice (Water GP) is\u00a0committed to Water for People and Planet. The SDGs provide an opportunity for the World Bank Group and development partners to work together in support of this vision.\n\nAnd, in 2019, the Water GP launched its new Strategic Action Plan. Our vision remains a Water Secure World for All, to be delivered through three inter-related pillars: (1)\u00a0sustain water resources, (2)\u00a0deliver services, and (3)\u00a0build resilience. The World Bank has played a key role in driving delivery when it comes to the SDGs. We continue to implement programs and projects across the world, convene a wide range of actors to achieve cross-sectoral solutions, and share our data, knowledge and know-how with others in service of a water-secure world for all.\n\nWith a portfolio of water investments of almost US$30 billion and a staff of hundreds of water experts across the world, the Water GP is uniquely positioned to address these themes, developing and sharing global knowledge while amplifying the impact of lending through technical assistance on the ground.\n\nThe World Bank has identified five priority themes to achieve the Sustainable Development Goal in the water sector (SDG 6). To address the challenges of increasing water scarcity and variability and to ensure that results are maintained in the future, a renewed focus on the multiple facets of resilience and sustainability is needed. However, without new efforts to improve inclusion, many will still be unable to reap the benefits of water and will be disproportionately impacted by water-related disasters.\n\nHelping countries achieve greater sustainability and inclusion in the water sector requires investment in institutions, to complement the traditional focus on building infrastructure. Building the institutions and infrastructure needed for universal access and more sustainable water management practices also demands a vast increase in financing for the water sector, which can only be achieved by improving financial viability and leveraging donor funding to tap other sources of finance.\n\nThese five priority themes form the core of a partnership for a water-secure world, supported by the \u3010340\u2020Global Water Security &amp; Sanitation Partnership (GWSP)\u3011. [Image 8: Medical]Safe WASH services in health care facilities (HCFs) to deliver quality health services; protect patients, health workers, and staff; and to prevent further transmission. The WASH in Health Care Facilities Global Baseline Report (JMP, 2019) highlighted that one in four HCFs lacks basic water service (affecting more than 900 million people), one in five HCFs has no sanitation service (affecting about 1.5 billion people), and one in six HCFs has no hygiene service.
