Support should ensure services are not disrupted and products such as soap and alcohol-based hand rubs are available. These services should also be available in temporary HCFs and quarantine sites.\u00a0\n\n  2. [Image 9: Sign Language]Improving handwashing behavior, food hygiene, and safe water practices. Materials for handwashing and hygiene may include provision of fixed and portable handwashing facilities, purchase of soap and alcohol-based hand rubs, provision of water supplies for handwashing, and point of use water treatment. Schools, workplaces, markets, transport stations, and other areas where people gather all require easy access to handwashing facilities and water and soap for handwashing. Proven behavior change techniques can help increase the frequency and improve the practice of critical hygiene behaviors. Resources such as the\u00a0\u3010342\u2020Global Handwashing Partnership\u2020globalhandwashing.org\u3011\u00a0can be tapped to mobilize private, public, and civil society actors to support developing messaging and materials to respond to COVID-19 outbreaks in country.\u00a0\n\n  3. Emergency support to secure and extend water and sanitation service provision, including:\n\n  * [Image 10: Sink]Rapid and low-cost water service and sanitation provision for communities, health care facilities, and schools is critical to enable handwashing, hygiene, and disinfection. According to\u00a0\u3010343\u2020UN Habitat\u2020unhabitat.org\u3011, COVID-19 will hit the world\u2019s most vulnerable people the most, many of whom live in informal settlements and rural community settings. Providing quick, just-in-time community water access points/water kiosks (including provision of soap) in unserved urban and rural areas, and for unserved HCFs and schools is critical. This could include: (i) provision and operation of compact water treatment plants; (ii) construction and operation of water points and sanitation facilities to deliver water in strategic urban or rural points; and/or (iii) provis", "pub_date": null, "extra": {"cited_message_idx": 9, "search_result_idx": null, "evidence_text": "source"}}}, {"start_ix": 2037, "end_ix": 2047, "citation_format_type": "tether_og", "metadata": {"type": "webpage", "title": "Water Overview: Development news, research, data | World Bank", "url": "https://www.worldbank.org/en/topic/water/overview", "text": "\n#### \u00a0\n\n#### \u3010337\u2020 View the Dam Safety Infographic&gt;&gt;\u3011\n\n#### \u00a0\n\n#### \u3010338\u2020 View the Social Inclusion Infographic&gt;&gt;\u3011\n\n#### \u00a0\n\n#### \u3010339\u2020 View the Climate Change and Water Infographic&gt;&gt;\u3011\n\n#### \u00a0\n\n#### \u00a0\n\nLast Updated:\u00a0Jul 28, 2023\n\nIn response to the water and sanitation crisis, the World Bank Water Global Practice (Water GP) is\u00a0committed to Water for People and Planet. The SDGs provide an opportunity for the World Bank Group and development partners to work together in support of this vision.\n\nAnd, in 2019, the Water GP launched its new Strategic Action Plan. Our vision remains a Water Secure World for All, to be delivered through three inter-related pillars: (1)\u00a0sustain water resources, (2)\u00a0deliver services, and (3)\u00a0build resilience. The World Bank has played a key role in driving delivery when it comes to the SDGs. We continue to implement programs and projects across the world, convene a wide range of actors to achieve cross-sectoral solutions, and share our data, knowledge and know-how with others in service of a water-secure world for all.\n\nWith a portfolio of water investments of almost US$30 billion and a staff of hundreds of water experts across the world, the Water GP is uniquely positioned to address these themes, developing and sharing global knowledge while amplifying the impact of lending through technical assistance on the ground.\n\nThe World Bank has identified five priority themes to achieve the Sustainable Development Goal in the water sector (SDG 6). To address the challenges of increasing water scarcity and variability and to ensure that results are maintained in the future, a renewed focus on the multiple facets of resilience and sustainability is needed. However, without new efforts to improve inclusion, many will still be unable to reap the benefits of water and will be disproportionately impacted by water-related disasters.\n\nHelping countries achieve greater sustainability and inclusion in the water sector requires investment in institutions, to complement the traditional focus on building infrastructure. Building the institutions and infrastructure needed for universal access and more sustainable water management practices also demands a vast increase in financing for the water sector, which can only be achieved by improving financial viability and leveraging donor funding to tap other sources of finance.\n\nThese five priority themes form the core of a partnership for a water-secure world, supported by the \u3010340\u2020Global Water Security &amp; Sanitation Partnership (GWSP)\u3011. This is a Multi-Donor Trust Fund, launched in 2017 that enables the Water GP to address the five themes across its global portfolio.\n\nTo more effectively bring critical resources to the front lines, the GWSP has been designed as a Water GP core asset\u2014its \u201cthink-tank\u201d\u2014which expands and deepens the impact of its lending program.\n\nIn 2018, the \u3010341\u20202030 Water Resources Group (2030 WRG)\u2020www.2030wrg.org\u3011\u00a0\u2014 a public-private-civil society partnership \u2014 became part of the Water GP family. 2030 WRG supports government-accelerated reforms with the aim of ensuring sustainable water resources management for long-term development and economic growth.\n\nTo respond to COVID-19, action in the WASH sector is critical for both containing the virus and lowering its immediate impact and aftermath. Three priority areas are identified as part of the emergency response:\n\n  1. [Image 8: Medical]Safe WASH services in health care facilities (HCFs) to deliver quality health services; protect patients, health workers, and staff; and to prevent further transmission. The WASH in Health Care Facilities Global Baseline Report (JMP, 2019) highlighted that one in four HCFs lacks basic water service (affecting more than 900 million people), one in five HCFs has no sanitation service (affecting about 1.5 billion people), and one in six HCFs has no hygiene service. During an infectious disease outbreak, services should meet minimum quality standards and should be separated for infected vs. non-infected patients. Support should ensure services are not disrupted and products such as soap and alcohol-based hand rubs are available. These services should also be available in temporary HCFs and quarantine sites.\u00a0\n\n  2. [Image 9: Sign Language]Improving handwashing behavior, food hygiene, and safe water practices. Materials for handwashing and hygiene may include provision of fixed and portable handwashing facilities, purchase of soap and alcohol-based hand rubs, provision of water supplies for handwashing, and point of use water treatment. Schools, workplaces, markets, transport stations, and other areas where people gather all require easy access to handwashing facilities and water and soap for handwashing. Proven behavior change techniques can help increase the frequency and improve the practice of critical hygiene behaviors. Resources such as the\u00a0\u3010342\u2020Global Handwashing Partnership\u2020globalhandwashing.org\u3011\u00a0can be tapped to mobilize private, public, and civil society actors to support developing messaging and materials to respond to COVID-19 outbreaks in country.\u00a0\n\n  3. Emergency support to secure and extend water and sanitation service provision, including:\n\n  * [Image 10: Sink]Rapid and low-cost water service and sanitation provision for communities, health care facilities, and schools is critical to enable handwashing, hygiene, and disinfection. According to\u00a0\u3010343\u2020UN Habitat\u2020unhabitat.org\u3011, COVID-19 will hit the world\u2019s most vulnerable people the most, many of whom live in informal settlements and rural community settings. Providing quick, just-in-time community water access points/water kiosks (including provision of soap) in unserved urban and rural areas, and for unserved HCFs and schools is critical. This could include: (i) provision and operation of compact water treatment plants; (ii) construction and operation of water points and sanitation facilities to deliver water in strategic urban or rural points; and/or (iii) provis", "pub_date": null, "extra": {"cited_message_idx": 9, "search_result_idx": null, "evidence_text": "source"}}}, {"start_ix": 2362, "end_ix": 2372, "citation_format_type": "tether_og", "metadata": {"type": "webpage", "title": "Water Overview: Development news, research, data | World Bank", "url": "https://www.worldbank.org/en/topic/water/overview", "text": "\n#### \u00a0\n\n#### \u3010337\u2020 View the Dam Safety Infographic&gt;&gt;\u3011\n\n#### \u00a0\n\n#### \u3010338\u2020 View the Social Inclusion Infographic&gt;&gt;\u3011\n\n#### \u00a0\n\n#### \u3010339\u2020 View the Climate Change and Water Infographic&gt;&gt;\u3011\n\n#### \u00a0\n\n#### \u00a0\n\nLast Updated:\u00a0Jul 28, 2023\n\nIn response to the water and sanitation crisis, the World Bank Water Global Practice (Water GP) is\u00a0committed to Water for People and Planet. The SDGs provide an opportunity for the World Bank Group and development partners to work together in support of this vision.\n\nAnd, in 2019, the Water GP launched its new Strategic Action Plan. Our vision remains a Water Secure World for All, to be delivered through three inter-related pillars: (1)\u00a0sustain water resources, (2)\u00a0deliver services, and (3)\u00a0build resilience. The World Bank has played a key role in driving delivery when it comes to the SDGs. We continue to implement programs and projects across the world, convene a wide range of actors to achieve cross-sectoral solutions, and share our data, knowledge and know-how with others in service of a water-secure world for all.\n\nWith a portfolio of water investments of almost US$30 billion and a staff of hundreds of water experts across the world, the Water GP is uniquely positioned to address these themes, developing and sharing global knowledge while amplifying the impact of lending through technical assistance on the ground.\n\nThe World Bank has identified five priority themes to achieve the Sustainable Development Goal in the water sector (SDG 6). To address the challenges of increasing water scarcity and variability and to ensure that results are maintained in the future, a renewed focus on the multiple facets of resilience and sustainability is needed. However, without new efforts to improve inclusion, many will still be unable to reap the benefits of water and will be disproportionately impacted by water-related disasters.\n\nHelping countries achieve greater sustainability and inclusion in the water sector requires investment in institutions, to complement the traditional focus on building infrastructure. Building the institutions and infrastructure needed for universal access and more sustainable water management practices also demands a vast increase in financing for the water sector, which can only be achieved by improving financial viability and leveraging donor funding to tap other sources of finance.\n\nThese five priority themes form the core of a partnership for a water-secure world, supported by the \u3010340\u2020Global Water Security &amp; Sanitation Partnership (GWSP)\u3011. This is a Multi-Donor Trust Fund, launched in 2017 that enables the Water GP to address the five themes across its global portfolio.\n\nTo more effectively bring critical resources to the front lines, the GWSP has been designed as a Water GP core asset\u2014its \u201cthink-tank\u201d\u2014which expands and deepens the impact of its lending program.\n\nIn 2018, the \u3010341\u20202030 Water Resources Group (2030 WRG)\u2020www.2030wrg.org\u3011\u00a0\u2014 a public-private-civil society partnership \u2014 became part of the Water GP family. 2030 WRG supports government-accelerated reforms with the aim of ensuring sustainable water resources management for long-term development and economic growth.\n\nTo respond to COVID-19, action in the WASH sector is critical for both containing the virus and lowering its immediate impact and aftermath. Three priority areas are identified as part of the emergency response:\n\n  1. [Image 8: Medical]Safe WASH services in health care facilities (HCFs) to deliver quality health services; protect patients, health workers, and staff; and to prevent further transmission. The WASH in Health Care Facilities Global Baseline Report (JMP, 2019) highlighted that one in four HCFs lacks basic water service (affecting more than 900 million people), one in five HCFs has no sanitation service (affecting about 1.5 billion people), and one in six HCFs has no hygiene service. During an infectious disease outbreak, services should meet minimum quality standards and should be separated for infected vs. non-infected patients. Support should ensure services are not disrupted and products such as soap and alcohol-based hand rubs are available. These services should also be available in temporary HCFs and quarantine sites.\u00a0\n\n  2. [Image 9: Sign Language]Improving handwashing behavior, food hygiene, and safe water practices. Materials for handwashing and hygiene may include provision of fixed and portable handwashing facilities, purchase of soap and alcohol-based hand rubs, provision of water supplies for handwashing, and point of use water treatment. Schools, workplaces, markets, transport stations, and other areas where people gather all require easy access to handwashing facilities and water and soap for handwashing. Proven behavior change techniques can help increase the frequency and improve the practice of critical hygiene behaviors. Resources such as the\u00a0\u3010342\u2020Global Handwashing Partnership\u2020globalhandwashing.org\u3011\u00a0can be tapped to mobilize private, public, and civil society actors to support developing messaging and materials to respond to COVID-19 outbreaks in country.\u00a0\n\n  3. Emergency support to secure and extend water and sanitation service provision, including:\n\n  * [Image 10: Sink]Rapid and low-cost water service and sanitation provision for communities, health care facilities, and schools is critical to enable handwashing, hygiene, and disinfection. According to\u00a0\u3010343\u2020UN Habitat\u2020unhabitat.org\u3011, COVID-19 will hit the world\u2019s most vulnerable people the most, many of whom live in informal settlements and rural community settings. Providing quick, just-in-time community water access points/water kiosks (including provision of soap) in unserved urban and rural areas, and for unserved HCFs and schools is critical. This could include: (i) provision and operation of compact water treatment plants; (ii) construction and operation of water points and sanitation facilities to deliver water in strategic urban or rural points; and/or (iii) provis", "pub_date": null, "extra": {"cited_message_idx": 9, "search_result_idx": null, "evidence_text": "source"}}}, {"start_ix": 2620, "end_ix": 2631, "citation_format_type": "tether_og", "metadata": {"type": "webpage", "title": "Global Water Security and Sanitation Partnership: Annual Report 2023", "url": "https://www.worldbank.org/en/topic/water/publication/global-water-security-and-sanitation-partnership-annual-report-2023", "text": "\nRegions\n\n    * \u3010293\u2020Africa\u3011\n    * \u3010294\u2020East Asia and Pacific\u3011\n    * \u3010295\u2020Europe and Central Asia\u3011\n    * \u3010296\u2020Latin America and Caribbean\u3011\n    * \u3010297\u2020Middle East and North Africa\u3011\n    * \u3010298\u2020South Asia\u3011\n\nCountry Groups\n\n    * \u3010299\u2020European Union\u3011\n    * \u3010300\u2020Middle Income Countries\u3011\n    * \u301062\u2020Organization of Eastern Caribbean States\u3011\n    * \u3010133\u2020Pacific Islands\u3011\n    * \u3010301\u2020Small States\u3011\n    * \u3010302\u2020Gulf Cooperation Council\u3011\n    * \u3010132\u2020Western Europe\u3011\n\n  * \u30105\u2020UNDERSTANDING POVERTY\u3011 \n\n[Image 3: megamenu-image-1] \n\nWe face big challenges to help the world\u2019s poorest people and ensure that everyone sees benefits from economic growth. Annual Meetings\u3011\n\n* * *\n\n    * \u3010326\u2020 Contacts &amp; Inquiries \u3011\n\n  * [Image 4: WB Live]\n\nglobal Search dropdown\n\n[Image 5: Search graphic]\n\nSearch\n\n    Search button\n\n  1. \u30105\u2020Understanding Poverty\u3011\n  2. \u301048\u2020Topics\u3011\n  3. \u3010327\u2020Water \u3011\n\npublication November 16, 2023\n\n# Global Water Security and Sanitation Partnership: Annual Report 2023\n\n  *  \n  * \u3010328\u2020 \u3011 \n  *  \n  *  \n  *  \n  *  Share more\n\nclose\n\n    * [Image 6: Image] linkedin\n    * [Image 7: Image] digg\n    * [Image 8: Image] renren\n    * [Image 9: Image] stumbleupon\n    * [Image 10: Image] delicious\n    * [Image 11: Image] sina\n\n* * *\n\n[Image 12: Cover image of the GWSP 2023 Annual Report] \n\n* * *\n\nThe world is not on track with meeting the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). As of 2022, 2.2 billion people lacked safely managed drinking water, 3.5 billion lacked access to safely managed sanitation, and 2 billion lacked access to basic hand hygiene facilities. Today, global investment needs in the water sector exceed $1.37 trillion. To meet SDG 6 by 2030, investments must increase sixfold from the current level. Scaling up water investments will result in healthier people and ecosystems, climate-resilient irrigation and drainage services for farmers and improved water storage. In fiscal year 2023, the World Bank saw increased demand from client countries for assistance in building effective and efficient institutions for delivery of water and sanitation services, achieving climate-resilient irrigation, and managing worsening flood and drought risks. GWSP provided support for designing and implementing projects that are sustainable and resilient as well as inclusive policy advice. Over the past year, GWSP informed more than $13.5 billion of World Bank projects. Below are some of the highlights from GWSP in 2023.\n\nDownload the 2023 Global Water and Sanitation Partnership Annual Report \u3010329\u2020here\u2020documents1.worldbank.org\u3011.\n\nKEY MESSAGES:\n\nWith billions of people at risk, the global water crisis demands accelerated action.\n\n  * In 2022, 2.2 billion people lacked safely managed drinking water, 3.5 billion lacked safely managed sanitation, and 2 billion lacked basic hygiene services.\n  * Unaddressed, the water crisis may result in global, national, and regional conflicts.\n  * Investing in water will result in healthier people, economies, and ecosystems.\n  * We must act quickly, collectively, and on a much larger scale if we are to meet the water-related SDGs by 2030.\n\nAs a center of excellence for water-related issues, we are well positioned to help countries accelerate action on water.\n\n  * GWSP is a platform for collaboration and support of the water-related SDGs. We drive policy changes, b", "pub_date": null, "extra": {"cited_message_idx": 12, "search_result_idx": null, "evidence_text": "source"}}}, {"start_ix": 2864, "end_ix": 2875, "citation_format_type": "tether_og", "metadata": {"type": "webpage", "title": "Global Water Security and Sanitation Partnership: Annual Report 2023", "url": "https://www.worldbank.org/en/topic/water/publication/global-water-security-and-sanitation-partnership-annual-report-2023", "text": "\nRegions\n\n    * \u3010293\u2020Africa\u3011\n    * \u3010294\u2020East Asia and Pacific\u3011\n    * \u3010295\u2020Europe and Central Asia\u3011\n    * \u3010296\u2020Latin America and Caribbean\u3011\n    * \u3010297\u2020Middle East and North Africa\u3011\n    * \u3010298\u2020South Asia\u3011\n\nCountry Groups\n\n    * \u3010299\u2020European Union\u3011\n    * \u3010300\u2020Middle Income Countries\u3011\n    * \u301062\u2020Organization of Eastern Caribbean States\u3011\n    * \u3010133\u2020Pacific Islands\u3011\n    * \u3010301\u2020Small States\u3011\n    * \u3010302\u2020Gulf Cooperation Council\u3011\n    * \u3010132\u2020Western Europe\u3011\n\n  * \u30105\u2020UNDERSTANDING POVERTY\u3011 \n\n[Image 3: megamenu-image-1] \n\nWe face big challenges to help the world\u2019s poorest people and ensure that everyone sees benefits from economic growth. As of 2022, 2.2 billion people lacked safely managed drinking water, 3.5 billion lacked access to safely managed sanitation, and 2 billion lacked access to basic hand hygiene facilities. Today, global investment needs in the water sector exceed $1.37 trillion. To meet SDG 6 by 2030, investments must increase sixfold from the current level. Scaling up water investments will result in healthier people and ecosystems, climate-resilient irrigation and drainage services for farmers and improved water storage. In fiscal year 2023, the World Bank saw increased demand from client countries for assistance in building effective and efficient institutions for delivery of water and sanitation services, achieving climate-resilient irrigation, and managing worsening flood and drought risks. GWSP provided support for designing and implementing projects that are sustainable and resilient as well as inclusive policy advice. Over the past year, GWSP informed more than $13.5 billion of World Bank projects. Annual Meetings\u3011\n\n* * *\n\n    * \u3010326\u2020 Contacts &amp; Inquiries \u3011\n\n  * [Image 4: WB Live]\n\nglobal Search dropdown\n\n[Image 5: Search graphic]\n\nSearch\n\n    Search button\n\n  1. \u30105\u2020Understanding Poverty\u3011\n  2. \u301048\u2020Topics\u3011\n\nThis page in: \n\n English \n\n  * \u3010327\u2020Espa\u00f1ol\u2020www.bancomundial.org\u3011\n  * \u3010328\u2020\u0627\u0644\u0639\u0631\u0628\u064a\u0629\u2020www.albankaldawli.org\u3011\n  * \u3010329\u2020Fran\u00e7ais\u2020www.banquemondiale.org\u3011\n\nThis page in: English\n\n  * \u3010327\u2020Espa\u00f1ol\u2020www.bancomundial.org\u3011 \n  * \u3010328\u2020\u0627\u0644\u0639\u0631\u0628\u064a\u0629\u2020www.albankaldawli.org\u3011 \n  * \u3010329\u2020Fran\u00e7ais\u2020www.banquemondiale.org\u3011 \n\n[Image 6: The World Bank] \n\n# WATER RESOURCES MANAGEMENT\n\nWater scarcity affects more than 40% of the global population. Water-related disasters account for 70% of all deaths related to natural disasters. The World Bank helps countries ensure sustainability of water use, build climate resilience and strengthen integrated management.\n\n  * Context &amp; Challenges\n  * Strategy\n  * Results &amp; Initiatives\n\nToday, most countries are placing unprecedented pressure on water resources. The global population is growing fast, and estimates show that with current practices, the world will face a 40% shortfall between forecast demand and available supply of water by 2030. Furthermore, chronic water scarcity, hydrological uncertainty, and extreme weather events (floods and droughts) are perceived as some of the biggest threats to global prosperity and stability. Acknowledgment of the role that water scarcity and drought are playing in aggravating fragility and conflict is increasing.\n\n\u3010330\u2020 \u3011\n\n\u3010330\u2020 \u3011\n\n\u3010330\u2020View the Full Infographic&gt;&gt;\u3011\n\nFeeding \u3010331\u202010 billion people by 2050 will require a 50% increase in agricultural production\u2020www.unwater.org\u3011, (which consumes 70% of the resource today), and a 15%\u00a0increase in water withdrawals. Besides this increasing demand, the resource is already scarce in many parts of the world. Estimates indicate that over 40% of the world population live in water scarce areas, and approximately \u00bc of world\u2019s GDP is exposed to this challenge. \u3010332\u2020By 2040, an estimated one in four children will live in areas with extreme water shortages\u2020mcas-proxyweb.mcas.ms\u3011.\u00a0Water security is a major \u2013 and often growing \u2013challenge for many countries today.\n\nClimate change will worsen the situation by altering hydrological cycles, making water more unpredictable and increasing the frequency and intensity of floods and droughts. The roughly 1 billion people living in monsoonal basins and the 500 million people living in deltas are especially vulnerable.\u00a0 Flood damages are estimated around $120 billion per year (only from property damage), and droughts pose, among others, constraints to the rural poor, highly dependent on rainfall variability for subsistence.\u00a0\n\nThe fragmentation of this resource also constrains water security. There are 276 transboundary basins, shared by 148 countries, which account for 60% of the global freshwater flow. Similarly, 300 aquifers systems are transboundary in nature, with 2.5 billion people worldwide are dependent on groundwater. The challenges of fragmentation are often replicated at the national scale, meaning cooperation is needed to achieve optimal water resources management and development solutions for all riparians. To deal with these complex and interlinked water challenges, countries will need to improve the way they manage their water resources and associated services.\n\nTo strengthen water security against this backdrop of increasing demand, water scarcity, growing uncertainty, greater extremes, and fragmentation challenges, clients will need to invest in institutional strengthening, information management, and (natural and man-made) infrastructure development. Institutional tools such as legal and regulatory frameworks, water pricing, and incentives are needed to better allocate, regulate, and conserve water resources. Information systems are needed for resource monitoring, decision making under unce"}, {"matched_text": "\u301010\u2020source\u3011", "start_idx": 327, "end_idx": 338, "alt": null, "type": "webpage_extended", "title": "Clean water &amp; sanitation | SDG 6: Clean water &amp; sanitation", "url": "https://datatopics.worldbank.org/sdgatlas/goal-6-clean-water-and-sanitation/", "pub_date": null, "snippet": "\n# Water withdrawal has increased in many countries\n\n## Total freshwater withdrawal (billion m^{3}/year) and Total population\n\n[Image 8: Loading] \n\n\u301020\u2020Data\u3011 Image Copy Link\n\nSource: [link: http://fao.org/aquastat/statistics/query/index.html?lang=en FAO Aquastat database]. Retrieved from World Development Indicators ([link: https://data.worldbank.org/indicator/ER.H2O.FWTL.K3 ER.H2O.FWTL.K3], [link: https://data.worldbank.org/indicator/SP.POP.TOTL SP.POP.TOTL]).\n\nWater is essential to human needs, and a critical input to food production. Population growth naturally leads to more pressure on water resources, as illustrated by the correlation between population size and water withdrawals.\n\nWhile that correlation holds at the global level, there is significant variation from country to country.\n\nIn Uruguay for instance, water withdrawals have increased much faster than the population. This is partly explained by Uruguay\u2019s agricultural sector\u2019s specialization in water intensive products like beef, soybeans, and rice.\n\nIn contrast, owing to more efficient use of water resources, the United States has managed to withdraw less water over the same period of time, despite of a growing population.\n\nSource: [link: http://fao.org/aquastat/statistics/query/index.html?lang=en FAO Aquastat database]. Retrieved from World Development Indicators ([link: https://data.worldbank.org/indicator/ER.H2O.FWTL.K3 ER.H2O.FWTL.K3], [link: https://data.worldbank.org/indicator/SP.POP.TOTL SP.POP.TOTL]).\n\n* * *\n\nAround [emphasis: 70 percent] of global freshwater resources are used for [emphasis: agriculture].\n\n* * *\n\nIn low-income countries, water use in agriculture accounts for 90 percent of all water withdrawals. This is significantly less in high-income countries (44 percent), where a higher share of water goes to the industrial sector.\n\n# Agriculture is the main sector of water use\n\n## Water withdrawal by sector (% of total freshwater withdrawal) by income group, 2020\n\n[Image 9: Loading] \n\n\u301021\u2020Data\u3011 Image Copy Link\n\nSource: [link: http://fao.org/aquastat/statistics/query/index.html?lang=en FAO Aquastat database]. Retrieved from World Development Indicators ([link: https://data.worldbank.org/indicator/ER.H2O.FWTL.K3 ER.H2O.FWTL.K3], [link: https://data.worldbank.org/indicator/ER.H2O.FWAG.ZS ER.H2O.FWAG.ZS], [link: https://data.worldbank.org/indicator/ER.H2O.FWIN.ZS ER.H2O.FWIN.ZS], [link: https://data.worldbank.org/indicator/ER.H2O.FWDM.ZS ER.H2O.FWDM.ZS]).\n\nBetween 1960 and 2018, water withdrawals increased by 100 percent in agriculture, 90 percent in industry, and 300 percent in domestic use.[reference: UN-Water. 2021. [link: https://www.unwater.org/sites/default/files/app/uploads/2021/10/UN-Water-analytical-brief-Water-use-efficiency_October2021.pdf \u201cUN-Water Analytical Brief on Water Use Efficiency.\u201d] Geneva.] Although water use is becoming more efficient[reference: FAO (Food and Agriculture Organization). 2021. [link: https://www.fao.org/documents/card/en/c/cb6413en \u201cProgress on change in water-use efficiency: Global Status and Acceleration Needs for SDG Indicator 6.4.1.\u201d] Rome.] across all economic sectors, global demand for water is expected to keep increasing due to economic and population growth.[reference: WWAP (UNESCO World Water Assessment Programme). 2019. [link: https://unesdoc.unesco.org/ark:/48223/pf0000367306 \u201cWorld Water Development Report 2019: Leaving No One Behind.\u201d] Paris.] This growth is adding to pressure on water resources, while at the same time the water cycle is being impacted by climate change \u2013 two factors which may limit freshwater availability. It is therefore essential to monitor stress on water resources as an early warning indicator of potential scarcity.\n\n## Water stress: from global to local\n\n### Understanding water stress: What is water stress?\n\nThere are different ways of defining water stress.[footnote: Please see the following [link: https://www.mdpi.com/2073-4441/13/2/201 article.]] In this story, we will use the water stress indicator defined in SDG 6.4.2.[reference: United Nations Statistics Division. SDG Indicators Metadata repository. [link: https://unstats.un.org/sdgs/metadata/files/Metadata-06-04-02.pdf \u201cIndicator 6.4.2: Level of water stress - Definition and methodology\u201d].] The water stress indicator seeks to estimate the amount of pressure on a country\u2019s renewable freshwater resources.[footnote: The indicator for water stress does not consider human-made increases in water supply (such as desalination), and ignores water withdrawals that are recycled and reused.] It is defined as the ratio of total freshwater withdrawals divided by the available renewable freshwater.\n\nThe closer a country gets to 100 percent, the more pressure it places on its water resources. In some cases, the value of 100 percent can even be exceeded. This happens when a country consumes water resources that are non-renewable. This is the "}, {"matched_text": "\u301010\u2020source\u3011", "start_idx": 553, "end_idx": 564, "alt": null, "type": "webpage_extended", "title": "Clean water &amp; sanitation | SDG 6: Clean water &amp; sanitation", "url": "https://datatopics.worldbank.org/sdgatlas/goal-6-clean-water-and-sanitation/", "pub_date": null, "snippet": "\n# Water withdrawal has increased in many countries\n\n## Total freshwater withdrawal (billion m^{3}/year) and Total population\n\n[Image 8: Loading] \n\n\u301020\u2020Data\u3011 Image Copy Link\n\nSource: [link: http://fao.org/aquastat/statistics/query/index.html?lang=en FAO Aquastat database]. Population growth naturally leads to more pressure on water resources, as illustrated by the correlation between population size and water withdrawals.\n\nWhile that correlation holds at the global level, there is significant variation from country to country.\n\nIn Uruguay for instance, water withdrawals have increased much faster than the population. This is partly explained by Uruguay\u2019s agricultural sector\u2019s specialization in water intensive products like beef, soybeans, and rice.\n\nIn contrast, owing to more efficient use of water resources, the United States has managed to withdraw less water over the same period of time, despite of a growing population.\n\nSource: [link: http://fao.org/aquastat/statistics/query/index.html?lang=en FAO Aquastat database]. Water-related disasters account for 70% of all deaths related to natural disasters. The World Bank helps countries ensure sustainability of water use, build climate resilience and strengthen integrated management.\n\n  * Context &amp; Challenges\n  * Strategy\n  * Results &amp; Initiatives\n\nToday, most countries are placing unprecedented pressure on water resources. The global population is growing fast, and estimates show that with current practices, the world will face a 40% shortfall between forecast demand and available supply of water by 2030. Furthermore, chronic water scarcity, hydrological uncertainty, and extreme weather events (floods and droughts) are perceived as some of the biggest threats to global prosperity and stability. Acknowledgment of the role that water scarcity and drought are playing in aggravating fragility and conflict is increasing.\n\n\u3010330\u2020 \u3011\n\n\u3010330\u2020 \u3011\n\n\u3010330\u2020View the Full Infographic&gt;&gt;\u3011\n\nFeeding \u3010331\u202010 billion people by 2050 will require a 50% increase in agricultural production\u2020www.unwater.org\u3011, (which consumes 70% of the resource today), and a 15%\u00a0increase in water withdrawals. Besides this increasing demand, the resource is already scarce in many parts of the world. Estimates indicate that over 40% of the world population live in water scarce areas, and approximately \u00bc of world\u2019s GDP is exposed to this challenge. \u3010332\u2020By 2040, an estimated one in four children will live in areas with extreme water shortages\u2020mcas-proxyweb.mcas.ms\u3011.\u00a0Water security is a major \u2013 and often growing \u2013challenge for many countries today.\n\nClimate change will worsen the situation by altering hydrological cycles, making water more unpredictable and increasing the frequency and intensity of floods and droughts. The roughly 1 billion people living in monsoonal basins and the 500 million people living in deltas are especially vulnerable.\u00a0 Flood damages are estimated around $120 billion per year (only from property damage), and droughts pose, among others, constraints to the rural poor, highly dependent on rainfall variability for subsistence.\u00a0\n\nThe fragmentation of this resource also constrains water security. There are 276 transboundary basins, shared by 148 countries, which account for 60% of the global freshwater flow. Similarly, 300 aquifers systems are transboundary in nature, with 2.5 billion people worldwide are dependent on groundwater. The challenges of fragmentation are often replicated at the national scale, meaning cooperation is needed to achieve optimal water resources management and development solutions for all riparians. To deal with these complex and interlinked water challenges, countries will need to improve the way they manage their water resources and associated services.\n\nTo strengthen water security against this backdrop of increasing demand, water scarcity, growing uncertainty, greater extremes, and fragmentation challenges, clients will need to invest in institutional strengthening, information management, and (natural and man-made) infrastructure development. Institutional tools such as legal and regulatory frameworks, water pricing, and incentives are needed to better allocate, regulate, and conserve water resources. Information systems are needed for resource monitoring, decision making under unce"}, {"matched_text": "\u30108\u2020source\u3011", "start_idx": 1233, "end_idx": 1243, "alt": null, "type": "webpage_extended", "title": "Water Resources Management Overview: Development news, research, data | World Bank", "url": "https://www.worldbank.org/en/topic/waterresourcesmanagement", "pub_date": null, "snippet": "    * \u3010303\u2020By Country\u2020data.worldbank.org\u3011\n    * \u3010304\u2020By Indicator\u2020data.worldbank.org\u3011\n    * \u301045\u2020Research &amp; Publications\u3011\n\nDevelopment Topics\n\n    * \u301040\u2020Climate Change\u3011\n    * \u3010305\u2020Agriculture and Food\u3011\n    * \u3010306\u2020Fragility, Conflict, and Violence\u3011\n    * \u3010307\u2020Poverty\u3011\n    * \u3010308\u2020Debt\u3011\n    * \u3010309\u2020Education\u3011\n    * \u3010310\u2020Health\u3011\n    * \u3010311\u2020Energy\u3011\n    * \u301041\u2020Food Security\u3011\n    * \u301048\u2020All Development Topics\u3011\n\n* * *\n\n    Search button\n\n  * \u30106\u2020WORK WITH US\u3011 \n\nFor Job Seekers\n\n    * \u3010312\u2020Jobs\u3011\n    * \u3010313\u2020Programs &amp; Internships\u3011\n\nFor Partners\n\n    * \u301011\u2020Partners\u3011\n    * \u3010314\u2020Corporate and Private Foundations\u3011\n    * \u3010315\u2020Clients\u2020clientconnection.worldbank.org\u3011\n    * \u3010316\u2020Private Sector\u3011\n    * \u3010317\u2020Corporate Procurement \u3011\n    * \u3010318\u2020Civil Society\u3011\n    * \u3010319\u2020Consultations\u2020consultations.worldbank.org\u3011\n    * \u3010320\u2020Parliamentarians\u3011\n\nFor Investors\n\n    * \u3010321\u2020World Bank Bonds &amp; Investment Products\u2020treasury.worldbank.org\u3011\n    * \u301052\u2020Treasury\u2020treasury.worldbank.org\u3011\n\nFor Learners\n\n    * \u301047\u2020Open Learning Campus\u2020olc.worldbank.org\u3011\n\nMeet Us\n\n    * \u3010322\u2020Events\u3011\n    * \u3010323\u2020World Bank Live\u2020live.worldbank.org\u3011\n    * \u3010324\u2020Speaker&#x27;s Bureau\u3011\n    * \u3010325\u2020Spring &amp; Annual Meetings\u3011\n\n* * *\n\n    * \u3010326\u2020 Contacts &amp; Inquiries \u3011\n\n  * [Image 4: WB Live]\n\nglobal Search dropdown\n\n[Image 5: Search graphic]\n\nSearch\n\n    Search button\n\n  1. \u30105\u2020Understanding Poverty\u3011\n  2. \u301048\u2020Topics\u3011\n\nThis page in: \n\n English \n\n  * \u3010327\u2020Espa\u00f1ol\u2020www.bancomundial.org\u3011\n  * \u3010328\u2020\u0627\u0644\u0639\u0631\u0628\u064a\u0629\u2020www.albankaldawli.org\u3011\n  * \u3010329\u2020Fran\u00e7ais\u2020www.banquemondiale.org\u3011\n\nThis page in: English\n\n  * \u3010327\u2020Espa\u00f1ol\u2020www.bancomundial.org\u3011 \n  * \u3010328\u2020\u0627\u0644\u0639\u0631\u0628\u064a\u0629\u2020www.albankaldawli.org\u3011 \n  * \u3010329\u2020Fran\u00e7ais\u2020www.banquemondiale.org\u3011 \n\n[Image 6: The World Bank] \n\n# WATER RESOURCES MANAGEMENT\n\nWater scarcity affects more than 40% of the global population. Water-related disasters account for 70% of all deaths related to natural disasters. The World Bank helps countries ensure sustainability of water use, build climate resilience and strengthen integrated management.\n\n  * Context &amp; Challenges\n  * Strategy\n  * Results &amp; Initiatives\n\nToday, most countries are placing unprecedented pressure on water resources. The global population is growing fast, and estimates show that with current practices, the world will face a 40% shortfall between forecast demand and available supply of water by 2030. Furthermore, chronic water scarcity, hydrological uncertainty, and extreme weather events (floods and droughts) are perceived as some of the biggest threats to global prosperity and stability. Acknowledgment of the role that water scarcity and drought are playing in aggravating fragility and conflict is increasing.\n\n\u3010330\u2020 \u3011\n\n\u3010330\u2020 \u3011\n\n\u3010330\u2020View the Full Infographic&gt;&gt;\u3011\n\nFeeding \u3010331\u202010 billion people by 2050 will require a 50% increase in agricultural production\u2020www.unwater.org\u3011, (which consumes 70% of the resource today), and a 15%\u00a0increase in water withdrawals. Besides this increasing demand, the resource is already scarce in many parts of the world. Estimates indicate that over 40% of the world population live in water scarce areas, and approximately \u00bc of world\u2019s GDP is exposed to this challenge. \u3010332\u2020By 2040, an estimated one in four children will live in areas with extreme water shortages\u2020mcas-proxyweb.mcas.ms\u3011.\u00a0Water security is a major \u2013 and often growing \u2013challenge for many countries today.\n\nClimate change will worsen the situation by altering hydrological cycles, making water more unpredictable and increasing the frequency and intensity of floods and droughts. The roughly 1 billion people living in monsoonal basins and the 500 million people living in deltas are especially vulnerable.\u00a0 Flood damages are estimated around $120 billion per year (only from property damage), and droughts pose, among others, constraints to the rural poor, highly dependent on rainfall variability for subsistence.\u00a0\n\nThe fragmentation of this resource also constrains water security. There are 276 transboundary basins, shared by 148 countries, which account for 60% of the global freshwater flow. Similarly, 300 aquifers systems are transboundary in nature, with 2.5 billion people worldwide are dependent on groundwater. The challenges of fragmentation are often replicated at the national scale, meaning cooperation is needed to achieve optimal water resources management and development solutions for all riparians. To deal with these complex and interlinked water challenges, countries will need to improve the way they manage their water resources and associated services.\n\nTo strengthen water security against this backdrop of increasing demand, water scarcity, growing uncertainty, greater extremes, and fragmentation challenges, clients will need to invest in institutional strengthening, information management, and (natural and man-made) infrastructure development. Institutional tools such as legal and regulatory frameworks, water pricing, and incentives are needed to better allocate, regulate, and conserve water resources. Information systems are needed for resource monitoring, decision making under unce"}, {"matched_text": "\u30109\u2020source\u3011", "start_idx": 1518, "end_idx": 1528, "alt": null, "type": "webpage_extended", "title": "Water Overview: Development news, research, data | World Bank", "url": "https://www.worldbank.org/en/topic/water/overview", "pub_date": null, "snippet": "\n#### \u00a0\n\n#### \u3010337\u2020 View the Dam Safety Infographic&gt;&gt;\u3011\n\n#### \u00a0\n\n#### \u3010338\u2020 View the Social Inclusion Infographic&gt;&gt;\u3011\n\n#### \u00a0\n\n#### \u3010339\u2020 View the Climate Change and Water Infographic&gt;&gt;\u3011\n\n#### \u00a0\n\n#### \u00a0\n\nLast Updated:\u00a0Jul 28, 2023\n\nIn response to the water and sanitation crisis, the World Bank Water Global Practice (Water GP) is\u00a0committed to Water for People and Planet. The SDGs provide an opportunity for the World Bank Group and development partners to work together in support of this vision.\n\nAnd, in 2019, the Water GP launched its new Strategic Action Plan. Our vision remains a Water Secure World for All, to be delivered through three inter-related pillars: (1)\u00a0sustain water resources, (2)\u00a0deliver services, and (3)\u00a0build resilience. The World Bank has played a key role in driving delivery when it comes to the SDGs. We continue to implement programs and projects across the world, convene a wide range of actors to achieve cross-sectoral solutions, and share our data, knowledge and know-how with others in service of a water-secure world for all.\n\nWith a portfolio of water investments of almost US$30 billion and a staff of hundreds of water experts across the world, the Water GP is uniquely positioned to address these themes, developing and sharing global knowledge while amplifying the impact of lending through technical assistance on the ground.\n\nThe World Bank has identified five priority themes to achieve the Sustainable Development Goal in the water sector (SDG 6). To address the challenges of increasing water scarcity and variability and to ensure that results are maintained in the future, a renewed focus on the multiple facets of resilience and sustainability is needed. However, without new efforts to improve inclusion, many will still be unable to reap the benefits of water and will be disproportionately impacted by water-related disasters.\n\nHelping countries achieve greater sustainability and inclusion in the water sector requires investment in institutions, to complement the traditional focus on building infrastructure. Building the institutions and infrastructure needed for universal access and more sustainable water management practices also demands a vast increase in financing for the water sector, which can only be achieved by improving financial viability and leveraging donor funding to tap other sources of finance.\n\nThese five priority themes form the core of a partnership for a water-secure world, supported by the \u3010340\u2020Global Water Security &amp; Sanitation Partnership (GWSP)\u3011. This is a Multi-Donor Trust Fund, launched in 2017 that enables the Water GP to address the five themes across its global portfolio.\n\nTo more effectively bring critical resources to the front lines, the GWSP has been designed as a Water GP core asset\u2014its \u201cthink-tank\u201d\u2014which expands and deepens the impact of its lending program.\n\nIn 2018, the \u3010341\u20202030 Water Resources Group (2030 WRG)\u2020www.2030wrg.org\u3011\u00a0\u2014 a public-private-civil society partnership \u2014 became part of the Water GP family. 2030 WRG supports government-accelerated reforms with the aim of ensuring sustainable water resources management for long-term development and economic growth.\n\nTo respond to COVID-19, action in the WASH sector is critical for both containing the virus and lowering its immediate impact and aftermath. Three priority areas are identified as part of the emergency response:\n\n  1. [Image 8: Medical]Safe WASH services in health care facilities (HCFs) to deliver quality health services; protect patients, health workers, and staff; and to prevent further transmission. The WASH in Health Care Facilities Global Baseline Report (JMP, 2019) highlighted that one in four HCFs lacks basic water service (affecting more than 900 million people), one in five HCFs has no sanitation service (affecting about 1.5 billion people), and one in six HCFs has no hygiene service. During an infectious disease outbreak, services should meet minimum quality standards and should be separated for infected vs. non-infected patients. Support should ensure services are not disrupted and products such as soap and alcohol-based hand rubs are available. These services should also be available in temporary HCFs and quarantine sites.\u00a0\n\n  2. [Image 9: Sign Language]Improving handwashing behavior, food hygiene, and safe water practices. Materials for handwashing and hygiene may include provision of fixed and portable handwashing facilities, purchase of soap and alcohol-based hand rubs, provision of water supplies for handwashing, and point of use water treatment. Schools, workplaces, markets, transport stations, and other areas where people gather all require easy access to handwashing facilities and water and soap for handwashing. Proven behavior change techniques can help increase the frequency and improve the practice of critical hygiene behaviors. Resources such as the\u00a0\u3010342\u2020Global Handwashing Partnership\u2020globalhandwashing.org\u3011\u00a0can be tapped to mobilize private, public, and civil society actors to support developing messaging and materials to respond to COVID-19 outbreaks in country.\u00a0\n\n  3. Emergency support to secure and extend water and sanitation service provision, including:\n\n  * [Image 10: Sink]Rapid and low-cost water service and sanitation provision for communities, health care facilities, and schools is critical to enable handwashing, hygiene, and disinfection. According to\u00a0\u3010343\u2020UN Habitat\u2020unhabitat.org\u3011, COVID-19 will hit the world\u2019s most vulnerable people the most, many of whom live in informal settlements and rural community settings. Providing quick, just-in-time community water access points/water kiosks (including provision of soap) in unserved urban and rural areas, and for unserved HCFs and schools is critical. This could include: (i) provision and operation of compact water treatment plants; (ii) construction and operation of water points and sanitation facilities to deliver water in strategic urban or rural points; and/or (iii) provis"}, {"matched_text": "\u30109\u2020source\u3011", "start_idx": 1834, "end_idx": 1844, "alt": null, "type": "webpage_extended", "title": "Water Overview: Development news, research, data | World Bank", "url": "https://www.worldbank.org/en/topic/water/overview", "pub_date": null, "snippet": "\n#### \u00a0\n\n#### \u3010337\u2020 View the Dam Safety Infographic&gt;&gt;\u3011\n\n#### \u00a0\n\n#### \u3010338\u2020 View the Social Inclusion Infographic&gt;&gt;\u3011\n\n#### \u00a0\n\n#### \u3010339\u2020 View the Climate Change and Water Infographic&gt;&gt;\u3011\n\n#### \u00a0\n\n#### \u00a0\n\nLast Updated:\u00a0Jul 28, 2023\n\nIn response to the water and sanitation crisis, the World Bank Water Global Practice (Water GP) is\u00a0committed to Water for People and Planet. Support should ensure services are not disrupted and products such as soap and alcohol-based hand rubs are available. These services should also be available in temporary HCFs and quarantine sites.\u00a0\n\n  2. [Image 9: Sign Language]Improving handwashing behavior, food hygiene, and safe water practices. Resources such as the\u00a0\u3010342\u2020Global Handwashing Partnership\u2020globalhandwashing.org\u3011\u00a0can be tapped to mobilize private, public, and civil society actors to support developing messaging and materials to respond to COVID-19 outbreaks in country.\u00a0\n\n  3. According to\u00a0\u3010343\u2020UN Habitat\u2020unhabitat.org\u3011, COVID-19 will hit the world\u2019s most vulnerable people the most, many of whom live in informal settlements and rural community settings. Providing quick, just-in-time community water access points/water kiosks (including provision of soap) in unserved urban and rural areas, and for unserved HCFs and schools is critical. The SDGs provide an opportunity for the World Bank Group and development partners to work together in support of this vision.\n\nAnd, in 2019, the Water GP launched its new Strategic Action Plan. Our vision remains a Water Secure World for All, to be delivered through three inter-related pillars: (1)\u00a0sustain water resources, (2)\u00a0deliver services, and (3)\u00a0build resilience. The World Bank has played a key role in driving delivery when it comes to the SDGs. We continue to implement programs and projects across the world, convene a wide range of actors to achieve cross-sectoral solutions, and share our data, knowledge and know-how with others in service of a water-secure world for all.\n\nWith a portfolio of water investments of almost US$30 billion and a staff of hundreds of water experts across the world, the Water GP is uniquely positioned to address these themes, developing and sharing global knowledge while amplifying the impact of lending through technical assistance on the ground.\n\nThe World Bank has identified five priority themes to achieve the Sustainable Development Goal in the water sector (SDG 6). To address the challenges of increasing water scarcity and variability and to ensure that results are maintained in the future, a renewed focus on the multiple facets of resilience and sustainability is needed. However, without new efforts to improve inclusion, many will still be unable to reap the benefits of water and will be disproportionately impacted by water-related disasters.\n\nHelping countries achieve greater sustainability and inclusion in the water sector requires investment in institutions, to complement the traditional focus on building infrastructure. Building the institutions and infrastructure needed for universal access and more sustainable water management practices also demands a vast increase in financing for the water sector, which can only be achieved by improving financial viability and leveraging donor funding to tap other sources of finance.\n\nThese five priority themes form the core of a partnership for a water-secure world, supported by the \u3010340\u2020Global Water Security &amp; Sanitation Partnership (GWSP)\u3011. This is a Multi-Donor Trust Fund, launched in 2017 that enables the Water GP to address the five themes across its global portfolio.\n\nTo more effectively bring critical resources to the front lines, the GWSP has been designed as a Water GP core asset\u2014its \u201cthink-tank\u201d\u2014which expands and deepens the impact of its lending program.\n\nIn 2018, the \u3010341\u20202030 Water Resources Group (2030 WRG)\u2020www.2030wrg.org\u3011\u00a0\u2014 a public-private-civil society partnership \u2014 became part of the Water GP family. 2030 WRG supports government-accelerated reforms with the aim of ensuring sustainable water resources management for long-term development and economic growth.\n\nTo respond to COVID-19, action in the WASH sector is critical for both containing the virus and lowering its immediate impact and aftermath. Three priority areas are identified as part of the emergency response:\n\n  1. [Image 8: Medical]Safe WASH services in health care facilities (HCFs) to deliver quality health services; protect patients, health workers, and staff; and to prevent further transmission. The WASH in Health Care Facilities Global Baseline Report (JMP, 2019) highlighted that one in four HCFs lacks basic water service (affecting more than 900 million people), one in five HCFs has no sanitation service (affecting about 1.5 billion people), and one in six HCFs has no hygiene service. During an infectious disease outbreak, services should meet minimum quality standards and should be separated for infected vs. non-infected patients. Support should ensure services are not disrupted and products such as soap and alcohol-based hand rubs are available. These services should also be available in temporary HCFs and quarantine sites.\u00a0\n\n  2. [Image 9: Sign Language]Improving handwashing behavior, food hygiene, and safe water practices. Materials for handwashing and hygiene may include provision of fixed and portable handwashing facilities, purchase of soap and alcohol-based hand rubs, provision of water supplies for handwashing, and point of use water treatment. Schools, workplaces, markets, transport stations, and other areas where people gather all require easy access to handwashing facilities and water and soap for handwashing. Proven behavior change techniques can help increase the frequency and improve the practice of critical hygiene behaviors. Resources such as the\u00a0\u3010342\u2020Global Handwashing Partnership\u2020globalhandwashing.org\u3011\u00a0can be tapped to mobilize private, public, and civil society actors to support developing messaging and materials to respond to COVID-19 outbreaks in country.\u00a0\n\n  3. Emergency support to secure and extend water and sanitation service provision, including:\n\n  * [Image 10: Sink]Rapid and low-cost water service and sanitation provision for communities, health care facilities, and schools is critical to enable handwashing, hygiene, and disinfection. According to\u00a0\u3010343\u2020UN Habitat\u2020unhabitat.org\u3011, COVID-19 will hit the world\u2019s most vulnerable people the most, many of whom live in informal settlements and rural community settings. Providing quick, just-in-time community water access points/water kiosks (including provision of soap) in unserved urban and rural areas, and for unserved HCFs and schools is critical. This could include: (i) provision and operation of compact water treatment plants; (ii) construction and operation of water points and sanitation facilities to deliver water in strategic urban or rural points; and/or (iii) provis"}, {"matched_text": "\u301012\u2020source\u3011", "start_idx": 2620, "end_idx": 2631, "alt": null, "type": "webpage_extended", "title": "Global Water Security and Sanitation Partnership: Annual Report 2023", "url": "https://www.worldbank.org/en/topic/water/publication/global-water-security-and-sanitation-partnership-annual-report-2023", "pub_date": null, "snippet": "\nRegions\n\n    * \u3010293\u2020Africa\u3011\n    * \u3010294\u2020East Asia and Pacific\u3011\n    * \u3010295\u2020Europe and Central Asia\u3011\n    * \u3010296\u2020Latin America and Caribbean\u3011\n    * \u3010297\u2020Middle East and North Africa\u3011\n    * \u3010298\u2020South Asia\u3011\n\nCountry Groups\n\n    * \u3010299\u2020European Union\u3011\n    * \u3010300\u2020Middle Income Countries\u3011\n    * \u301062\u2020Organization of Eastern Caribbean States\u3011\n    * \u3010133\u2020Pacific Islands\u3011\n    * \u3010301\u2020Small States\u3011\n    * \u3010302\u2020Gulf Cooperation Council\u3011\n    * \u3010132\u2020Western Europe\u3011\n\n  * \u30105\u2020UNDERSTANDING POVERTY\u3011 \n\n[Image 3: megamenu-image-1] \n\nWe face big challenges to help the world\u2019s poorest people and ensure that everyone sees benefits from economic growth. As of 2022, 2.2 billion people lacked safely managed drinking water, 3.5 billion lacked access to safely managed sanitation, and 2 billion lacked access to basic hand hygiene facilities. Today, global investment needs in the water sector exceed $1.37 trillion. To meet SDG 6 by 2030, investments must increase sixfold from the current level. Scaling up water investments will result in healthier people and ecosystems, climate-resilient irrigation and drainage services for farmers and improved water storage. In fiscal year 2023, the World Bank saw increased demand from client countries for assistance in building effective and efficient institutions for delivery of water and sanitation services, achieving climate-resilient irrigation, and managing worsening flood and drought risks. GWSP provided support for designing and implementing projects that are sustainable and resilient as well as inclusive policy advice. Over the past year, GWSP informed more than $13.5 billion of World Bank projects. Below are some of the highlights from GWSP in 2023.\n\nDownload the 2023 Global Water and Sanitation Partnership Annual Report \u3010329\u2020here\u2020documents1.worldbank.org\u3011.\n\nKEY MESSAGES:\n\nWith billions of people at risk, the global water crisis demands accelerated action.\n\n  * In 2022, 2.2 billion people lacked safely managed drinking water, 3.5 billion lacked safely managed sanitation, and 2 billion lacked basic hygiene services.\n  * Unaddressed, the water crisis may result in global, national, and regional conflicts.\n  * Investing in water will result in healthier people, economies, and ecosystems.\n  * We must act quickly, collectively, and on a much larger scale if we are to meet the water-related SDGs by 2030.\n\nAs a center of excellence for water-related issues, we are well positioned to help countries accelerate action on water.\n\n  * GWSP is a platform for collaboration and support of the water-related SDGs. The production volume of Soft Drinks in 2021 stood at 22363 Million Litres.\n\nB. Import volume decreased from 665.8 Million Litres in 2016 to 635.3 Million Litres in 2021.\n\nC. You are required to reference the readings and articles that provide evidence of effectiveness for your proposed plan. Give your paper a title, a brief introduction, and a conclusion. Adhere to the American Psychological Association (APA) guidelines for citation and references. The 3-5 page paper should be in the format of an impact assessment. Although olive oil itself is a renewable resource derived from olives, the environmental, social, and economic impacts of its production processes can align well with the assignment criteria. Here are a few angles to consider:\n\n### Sustainability Issues in Olive Oil Production\n1. **Water Usage**: Olive cultivation, especially in regions like the Mediterranean, requires substantial water resources, which can be problematic in water-scarce areas.\n2. **Land Use and Deforestation**: Intensive farming practices for olive production can lead to land degradation, loss of biodiversity, and deforestation.\n3. **Chemical Use**: The use of pesticides and fertilizers in olive farming can have detrimental effects on the soil quality and surrounding ecosystems.\n4. **Energy Consumption**: The processes of harvesting, pressing, and bottling olive oil can be energy-intensive, often relying on non-renewable energy sources.\n\n### Economic, Social, and Environmental Consequences\n- **Local Communities**: Assess how olive oil production affects local economies, including impacts on employment and local businesses.\n- **Global Markets**: Consider the economic ramifications on a global scale, including export markets and price volatility.\n- **Environmental Impact**: Analyze the carbon footprint, effects on local wildlife, and broader ecological impacts.\n\n### Regulation and Sustainability Initiatives\n- **Organic and Sustainable Certification**: Explore how these certifications affect practices and perceptions in the olive oil industry.\n- **EU Regulations and Subsidies**: Discuss how European policies (for major producers like Spain, Italy, and Greece) support or hinder sustainable practices.\n- **Water Management Policies**: Assess the role of local and regional water management policies in sustainable olive cultivation.\n\n### Conceptual and Analytical Frameworks\n- **Life Cycle Assessment (LCA)**: Conduct or review an LCA for olive oil to identify major environmental hotspots throughout the product&#x27;s life cycle.\n- **SWOT Analysis**: A Strengths, Weaknesses, Opportunities, and Threats analysis can help frame the economic and environmental aspects of olive oil production.\n\n### Presentation and Argument\nYour paper should culminate in a series of well-considered recommendations for improving sustainability within the industry. These could include advocating for stricter regulations on water usage, promoting organic farming practices, or encouraging the adoption of renewable energy sources in production processes.\n\n### Credible Sources\nMake sure to include academic journals, industry reports, and policy documents as sources. Here&#x27;s how this industry aligns with the assignment criteria and the broader theme of sustainability:\n\n### Sustainability Issues in the Water Bottling Industry\n1. **Resource Depletion**: Over-extraction of groundwater sources for bottling can lead to depletion of aquifers, especially in water-scarce areas. This can affect the availability of local water supplies.\n2. **Environmental Impact**: The production and disposal of plastic bottles cause significant environmental harm, including pollution and contribution to ocean plastic debris.\n3. **Carbon Footprint**: The transportation of bottled water, often across great distances, contributes to carbon emissions and global warming.\n\n### Economic, Social, and Environmental Consequences\n- **Local Communities**: In many cases, large bottling companies extract water from local sources, potentially limiting the community&#x27;s access to clean water, affecting agriculture, and local ecosystems.\n- **Economic Impact**: While the industry can generate significant revenue and jobs, it can also lead to water scarcity that might affect other local industries like agriculture or tourism.\n- **Environmental Degradation**: Bottling operations, including the use of resources for packaging and the energy consumed in production and distribution, have broad environmental impacts.\n\n### Regulation and Sustainability Initiatives\n- **Water Rights and Access**: Regulations around water rights, the licensing of water extraction, and the impact assessments required can either support sustainable practices or contribute to unsustainable exploitation.\n- **Recycling and Materials**: Policies encouraging or mandating the use of A notable location in Italy where water bottling has led to environmental and social issues is the region around the Acqua San Benedetto, which sources water from Scorz\u00e8, near Venice.\n\n### Key Points for the Case Study in Scorz\u00e8, Italy:\n\n1. **Local Impact**: Scorz\u00e8 is known for its high-quality groundwater resources, which are pivotal not only for local consumption but also for commercial bottling by companies like Acqua San Benedetto. The intensive extraction of water for bottling purposes raises concerns about sustainability and the long-term availability of these groundwater resources.\n\n2. **Environmental Concerns**: The extraction of large volumes of water can affect local water tables, potentially leading to decreased water availability for agricultural use in the region, which is vital for local farmers. There is also concern about the ecological impact on local wetlands and ecosystems that depend on stable groundwater levels.\n\n3. **Economic and Social Dimensions**: While the bottling industry provides employment opportunities and economic benefits through exports and local sales, there are tensions around the allocation of water resources. The local communities might face risks of water scarcity or restrictions on water use during dry periods, which can lead to social discontent.\n\n4. **Regulation and Policy**: Italy has regulations governing mineral water extraction, but the effectiveness and enforcement of these regulations can be a point of analysis. This includes how well these policies balance commercial interests with environmental sustainability and community rights to water access.\n\n5. **Sustainability Initiatives**: Investigating any existing sustainability initiatives by the bottling companies, such as efforts to reduce water usage, minimize environmental impact, or community engagement strategies, would provide insights into the industry&#x27;s response to sustainability challenges.\n\n### Why This Location is Suitable:\n- **Relevance**: The issue of water bottling in Scorz\u00e8 encapsulates the broader debates on water rights, commercial versus local needs, and sustainable resource management.\n- **Data Availability**: There is likely to be available data and research on water extraction volumes, environmental impact assessments, and regulatory documents specific to the region.\n- **Contrast and Comparisons**: Scorz\u00e8 offers a contrast to other global locations where bottled water is produced, allowing for comparative analysis of how different regulatory environments and community responses shape the sustainability of water resources.\n\nThis case study could enrich your paper by providing a specific example of how the global issues surrounding the water bottling industry manifest at a local level in Italy, highlighting the challenges and responses in a context known for its environmental beauty and significant agricultural output."]}, "status": "finished_successfully","end_turn": true

places like Scorz\u00e8, is indeed a suitable and compelling topic for your assignment. This industry, while not traditionally categorized with non-renewable resource industries like fracking or logging, can be framed within the context of non-renewable resource extraction due to the sustainability challenges it poses. Here&#x27;s how you can align this topic with the specific criteria of your assignment:\n\n1. **Clear, thorough, data-supported evidence of industry resource impacts**:\n   - Discuss the extraction rates of groundwater for bottling in Italy and the resultant strain on local aquifers. Use life cycle assessment (LCA) to trace the environmental footprint from extraction through to bottling and distribution.\n   - Map the process chain of water bottling to identify key stages where sustainability could be improved.\n\n4. **Policy framework for regulation is addressed and explained**:\n   - , "weight": 1.0, "metadata": {"citations": [], "gizmo_id": null, "message_type": null, "model_slug": "gpt-4", "default_model_slug": "gpt-4", "pad": "AAAAAAAAAAAAAA", "parent_id": "aaa2efea-08e7-44a5-8a64-48ec9d0b9e62", "finish_details": {"type": "stop", "stop_tokens": [100260]}, "is_complete": true, "request_id": "88b674b5cead0e4f-MXP", "timestamp_": "absolute"}, "recipient": "all", "channel": null}, "parent": "aaa2efea-08e7-44a5-8a64-48ec9d0b9e62", "children": ["aaa282dd-9a42-4547-b744-65ad392b1a82"]}, "aaa282dd-9a42-4547-b744-65ad392b1a82": {"id": "aaa282dd-9a42-4547-b744-65ad392b1a82", "message": {"id": "aaa282dd-9a42-4547-b744-65ad392b1a82", "author": {"role": "user", "name": null, "metadata": {}}, "create_time": 1717007112.645795, "update_time": null, "content": {"content_type": "text", "parts": ["question what exactly is the format  of an impact assessment? Any key elements or methods of going about it?"]}, "status": "finished_successfully", "end_turn": null, "weight": 1.0, "metadata": {"request_id": "88b88693eae20e03-MXP", "message_source": null, "timestamp_": "absolute", "message_type": null}, "recipient": "all", "channel": null}, "parent": "961e627a-85a2-4ea1-b953-4831ed28f985", "children": ["f1321832-adfe-4ec5-b785-7b62f46690be"]}, "f1321832-adfe-4ec5-b785-7b62f46690be": {"id": "f1321832-adfe-4ec5-b785-7b62f46690be", "message": {"id": "f1321832-adfe-4ec5-b785-7b62f46690be", "author": {"role": "assistant", "name": null, "metadata": {}}, "create_time": 1717007145.671221, "update_time": null, "content": {"content_type": "text", "parts": ["An impact assessment is a systematic approach used to evaluate the environmental, social, and economic effects of a project or policy before decisions are made. It aims to minimize adverse impacts and enhance positive outcomes. The format and structure of an impact assessment can vary depending on its focus and the regulatory context, but generally, it includes several key elements:\n\n### 1. **Description of the Project or Policy**\n   - **Objective**: Clearly define the objectives of the project or policy being assessed.\n   - **Scope**: Detail the geographical and temporal scope of the project or policy.\n   - **Activities Involved**: Outline the specific activities that will be undertaken as part of the project or policy.\n\n### 2. **Environmental, Social, and Economic Baseline Conditions**\n   - **Current State**: Describe the existing environmental, social, and economic conditions of the area or community that will be affected.\n   - **Data Collection**: This involves collecting data to establish a baseline for comparison. This can include demographic information, ecological data, economic statistics, etc.\n\n### 3. **Identification of Impacts**\n   - **Predicting Impacts**: Identify and predict the likely environmental, social, and economic impacts, both positive and negative, that could result from the project or policy.\n   - **Direct and Indirect Impacts**: Consider both direct impacts (e.g., pollution) and indirect impacts (e.g., increased local employment leading to urbanization).\n\n### 4. **Assessment of Impacts**\n   - **Magnitude and Significance**: Evaluate the magnitude and significance of each predicted impact. This often involves qualitative descriptions and quantitative measures.\n   - **Cumulative Impacts**: Assess the cumulative impacts in combination with other past, present, and reasonably foreseeable future projects.\n\n### 5. **Mitigation Measures**\n   - **Strategies to Avoid or Mitigate Negative Impacts**: Propose measures to avoid, minimize, rectify, or compensate for adverse impacts.\n   - **Enhancement Measures**: Suggest ways to enhance positive outcomes.\n\n### 6. **Consultation and Participation**\n   - **Stakeholder Engagement**: Document the process of consulting with stakeholders, including the public, experts, and governmental bodies.\n   - **Feedback Integration**: How the input from these stakeholders has been considered and integrated into the project or policy planning.\n\n### 7. **Monitoring and Management Plans**\n   - **Implementation of Mitigation**: Detail how the mitigation measures will be implemented and by whom.\n   - **Monitoring Plans**: Establish plans for monitoring the impacts and the effectiveness of mitigation measures over time.\n\n### 8. **Reporting**\n   - **Impact Assessment Report**: Prepare a comprehensive report that summarizes the findings, methodologies used, data collected, and recommendations for the project or policy.\n   - **Non-Technical Summary**: Provide a summary that is accessible to non-experts to ensure transparency and facilitate broader understanding.\n\n### 9. **Review and Decision-Making**\n   - **Review Process**: The impact assessment is typically reviewed by relevant authorities or independent experts to ensure it meets the required standards.\n   - **Decision**: The decision-makers use the impact assessment report to approve, modify, or reject the project or policy.\n\n### Methodological Approaches\n- **Scientific Research and Data Analysis**: Utilize relevant scientific methodologies to collect and analyze data.\n- **Comparative Analyses**: Compare predicted impacts against the baseline to assess relative changes.\n- **Public Participation Techniques**: Methods for engaging stakeholders effectively, such as surveys, public meetings, or focus groups.\n\nIncorporating these elements ensures that an impact assessment is thorough and provides a sound basis for making informed decisions that account for a range of consequences. In the context of your paper, this framework will allow you to systematically evaluate the impacts of the water bottling industry in Italy, consider stakeholders&#x27; perspectives, and propose grounded solutions."]}, "status": "finished_successfully","end_turn": true

as the focus of your assignment to discuss the displacement of workers and the concentration of economic benefits among a wealthy elite is an intriguing topic. However, it doesn&#x27;t directly align with the specific directive of the assignment, which asks for an analysis of a &quot;resource-extracting, non-renewable industry&quot; that creates social dilemmas through unsustainable practices.\n\nAI and robotics, as industries, generally involve technological innovation and manufacturing, which differ from traditional resource extraction like mining, logging, or fossil fuel extraction. These sectors are more about the creation and deployment of technology rather than the extraction of non-renewable natural resources. Here\u2019s how you might adjust or realign:\n\n### Adjusting the Focus to Fit the Assignment\nTo more closely align with the assignment\u2019s focus on non-renewable resource industries, consider industries where AI and robotics are applied and have significant environmental and social impacts. For instance:\n- **Mining and Automated Drilling**: These are classic examples of non-renewable resource extraction where AI and robotics are increasingly utilized. You could analyze how automation and robotics increase efficiency but also displace traditional jobs, potentially leading to local unemployment or social unrest, and how they enable faster resource depletion.\n- **Electronic Waste from Robotics**: If focusing more on the robotics industry, consider the life cycle of robots, which involves significant use of metals and rare earth elements that are non-renewable. The disposal of obsolete robots contributes to electronic waste, posing environmental and health hazards.\n\n### Suggested Structure for Impact Assessment\nIf you choose a more aligned topic within AI and robotics applications in a non-renewable resource context, here\u2019s how you might structure the paper:\n\n1. **Introduction**\n   - Describe how AI and robotics are used in the industry.\n   - Discuss the scale of the industry and its importance in global economic contexts.\n\n3. **Impact Assessment**\n   - **Social Impacts**: Analyze job displacement, changes in workforce skills requirements, and impacts on local communities.\n   - **Environmental Impacts**: Evaluate how AI and robotics might lead to faster depletion of non-renewable resources, or contribute to environmental degradation (e.g., increased waste).\n   - **Economic Impacts**: Discuss who benefits from the use of AI and robotics in the industry and how wealth is distributed.\n\n4. **Regulatory Frameworks**\n   - Review existing policies that regulate the use of technology in the industry.\n   - Discuss gaps in regulations that might allow unsustainable practices to proliferate.\n\n5. **Recommendations**\n   - Propose initiatives to mitigate negative impacts, such as retraining programs, stricter environmental regulations, or technology to reduce waste.\n   - Suggest policies to ensure more equitable benefits from technology use in the industry.\n\n6. **Conclusion**\n   -
