Its millions of givers and hundreds of thousands of\ncharitable organizations compose a kind of huge matrix of private legislatures that define social ills, set\n\ngoals and priorities, and methodically marshal resources to attack problems near at hand\u2014without\nasking the state&#x27;s permission. Admirers of participatory democracy ought to be excited by these mass\n\nactions. As Yale law professor Stephen Carter points out, individuals who give to charity often &quot;measure\n\nthe needs of the community by different calipers than centralized policy makers, and will therefore\ncontribute to a different set of  causes. These millions of individual decisions lead to a diversity in\n\nspending that would be impossible if we adopted the theory that the only money spent for the public\n\ngood is the money spent by the state.&quot; For this reason Carter refers to philanthropy as \u201cdemocracy in\naction.\u201d\n\nAlexis de Tocqueville said in Democracy in America that what impressed him about America&#x27;s voluntary\nactivity was not just the practical problems it solved, but the way the country&#x27;s hyperactive giving and\n\nvolunteering builds up the social muscles needed for a people to be self-governing. Philanthropy is not\njust a sign of self-rule,but also a source  of it\u2014a kind of nursery for broader loyalties to one&#x27;s fellow\n\ncitizens. A healthy democracy should encourage,not discourage,people from acting on their own to\n\nimprove what they judge to be the common good.\n\n8 .  Only government can lead important social change in a fair way!\n\nHistory tells a different story. Private donors and volunteers created the first schools,missions, colleges,\n\nand apprenticeships for Indians and African Americans,often in the face of state resistance.At the\n\nsame time government was enforcing Jim Crow laws,philanthropist Julius Rosenwald erected 4,977\n\nrural schools across America&#x27;s black belt. At the time of his death, 27 percent of all African American\n\nchildren in the United States were educated in one of the schools he built\n\n5/8https://ssir.org/articles/entry/12_common_crticisms_of_philanthropyand_some_answers#\n\n\n\n5/24/24,1:05 AM 12 Common Criticisms of Philanthropy\u2014and Some Answers\n\nThose who view such examples as ancient history and believe that all necessary reforms now flow from\ngovernment are gravely mistaken. According to the UCLA Civil Rights Project, America&#x27;s most\n\nsegregated and often most inadequate government-run schools are all in northern cities with activist\n\ngovernments: Detroit, Milwaukee, New York, Newark, Chicago, and Philadelphia. In fact,the country&#x27;s\n\nmost segregated schools are in New York state, thanks to New York City, where the proportion of\n\nschools in which at least go percent of the students are black or Hispanic rose sharply from 1989 to\n2OIO.\n\nIt is private philanthropy that is shaking up New York City&#x27;s complacent educational establishment\ntoday by launching charter schools. There are currently 95,ooo New York City children in charters,\nnearly all of them minorities and low-income, and another 42,6oo on waiting lists. Stanford researchers\nand other investigators find that these children are receiving significantly better educations than\ncounterparts in conventional government-run schools,in some cases even outscoring comfortable\nsuburban schools in annual testing.\n\n9. Some donors are mean,vainly seek their name on things, or take part in charity for all the wrong\nreasons!\n\nIt&#x27;s true that philanthropists aren&#x27;t always pretty. Prominent donors like J. Paul Getty, Leland Stanford,\nRussell Sage, and John MacArthur were known to exhibit shabby behavior. (Stanford, for example,\n\nemployed stock watering, kickbacks,bribery, and collusion.) Nonetheless, each ultimately managed to\nbe very helpful to others.\n\nThe genius of the philanthropic mechanism is that it accepts people just as they are\u2014kind impulses,\nselfish impulses,confusions and vanities,wishes of all sorts swirling together in the usual human\njumble\u2014and helps them do wondrous things,even when they&#x27;re not saints. Adam Smith taught us that\nfreely conducted commerce can take normal human behaviors\u2014including ugly and mercenary on es -\nand turn them to broadly productive uses.The same is true in the world of philanthropy.Part of the\nmagic of America&#x27;s charitable structure is that it can convert common human impulses into truth,\nuplift, and beauty for all of society.\n\nIo . Philanthropy distracts people who ought to focus on business!\n\nThe right side of the political spectrum sometimes complains that philanthropy drags too many\nproductive business people into do-gooding,distracting them from creating the commercial bounty that\n\n6/8https://ssir.org/articles/entry/12_common_crticisms_of_philanthropyand_some_answers#\n\n\n\n5/24/24,1:05 AM 12 Common Criticisms of Philanthropy\u2014and Some Answers\n\nsociety counts on. But there are reasons to think that philanthropy actually strengthens capitalism.\n\nEconomists Zoltan Acs and Ronnie Phillips have observed that the United States has a distinctive\n\nmeans of \u201creconstituting\u201d wealth via philanthropy.\u201cPhilanthropy is part of the implicit social contract\nthat continuously nurtures and revitalizes economic prosperity,&quot; they write. Researchers Tino and Nima\nSanandaji agree that the \u201clegitimacy of American capitalism has in part been upheld through voluntary\ndonations.&quot; They note that &quot;much of the new wealth created historically has been given back to society.\n\nThis has had several feedback effects on capitalism. For one, the practice has limited the rise of new\ndynasties. Another positive feedback mechanism is that the donations to research and higher education\nhave allowed new generations to become wealthy?\n\nII. Philanthropy encourages collective thinking, collective responsibility, and collective action\u2014\nultimately leading to more government!\n\nThis is another concern sometimes launched from the libertarian right, where observers argue that\n\nwhat American society really needs is more individual responsibility, not more giveaways. However, we\ncan just as plausibly turn that argument around, because there is evidence that philanthropy helps limit\n\ngovernment sprawl\n\nWhen some members of a society become needy, it is a fact that many citizens will insist,&quot;Something\n\nmust be done!&quot; Most times and places,the responsibility for picking up those in trouble has fallen to the\nstate. America&#x27;s energetic voluntary sector, however,allows Americans to meet humanitarian and Judeo-\n\nChristian responsibilities to their fellow humans without setting up large government apparatuses and\n\nregimenting rules that suffocate individual sovereignty\n\nBy solving basic security hungers and stretching multiple safety nets among the general populace,\n\nphilanthropy has made Americans much more tolerant of the creative destruction that&#x27;s part of  a\ndynamic economy, leaving us with a freer and faster-growing economy than comparable industrial\n\nnations. Philanthropy has thus been crucial in allowing America to grow up as an exceedingly rare\nsociety where average people can steer their own lives without the state lurking over their shoulder.\n\nI2. Donating money is sometimes too much about the giver&#x27;s needs!\n\nGiving is a two-way transaction,and the satisfactions of helping are just as real and just as good for\nhuman flourishing as the satisfactions of having someone come to your aid. That&#x27;s why even people\n\n7/8https://ssir.org/articles/entry/12_common_crticisms_of_philanthropyand_some_answers#\n\n\n\n5/24/24,1:05 AM 12 Common Criticisms of Philanthropy\u2014and Some Answers\n\nwith little disposable income are eager to give,and feel good when they do.\n\nSocial science research supports th is.In  a 20o8 paper, three investigators gave study participants\nmoney, and then asked half of them to spend it on themselves, and the other half to give it to some\n\nperson or charity.  Those who donated the money showed a significant uptick in happiness;those who\nspent it on themselves did not\n\nOther academic work has shown that offering aid can actually make the giver healthier\u2014lowering blood\n\npressure, stress, illness,and mortality. Americans who make gifts of money and time are more likely to\n\nprosper and be satisfied with life than non-givers who are demographically identical.  A 20I4 book by\n\ntwo University of Notre Dame researchers concludes, \u201cThe more generous Americans are, the more\n\nhappiness, health,and purpose in life they enjoy. This association \u22ef is strong and highly consistent.\u22ef\nGenerous practices actually create enhanced personal well-being.&quot;\n\nWe shouldn&#x27;t overlook\u2014or discount\u2014the good effects of giving on the giver.\n\nSupport SSIR&#x27;s coverage of cross-sector solutions to global challenges.\n\nHelp us further the reach of innovative ideas. Donate today\n\nRead more stories by Karl Zinsmeister.\n\nKarl Zinsmeister is creator of The Almanac of American Philanthropy, a new encyclopedic reference to the\nfield, just released by The Philanthropy Roundtable.\n\nDOI:1o.48558/jm4I-v703\n\nIf you like this article enough to print it, be sure to subscribe to SSIR!\n\nCopyright @ 2024 Stanford University.\nDesigned by Arsenal, developed by Hop Studios\n\n8/8https://ssir.org/articles/entry/12_common_critcisms_of_philanthropyand_some_answers#\n\n\n", "extra": {"cited_message_idx": 8, "search_result_idx": null, "evidence_text": "source"}, "url": "file-0ALsWs9dynkgdtMPP5VuvzmZ"}}, {"start_ix": 2334, "end_ix": 2344, "citation_format_type": "tether_og", "metadata": {"type": "file", "name": "week 4.2.pdf", "id": "file-633pKlwcrOvWVr7Ww0esX98g", "source": "my_files", "text": "\nH a rva rd\nB u s i n e s s\nR e v ie w\n\nCorporate Social Responsibility\n\nPhilanthropy&#x27;s New Agenda:\nCreating Value\nby Michael E. Porter and Mark R. Kramer\n\nFrom the Magazine (November-December 1999)\n\nDuring the past two decades,the number of charitable\nfoundations in the United States has doubled,while the value of\ntheir assets has increased more than 1,100%.Foundations now\nhold over $330 billion in assets and contribute over $20 billion\nannually to educational, humanitarian,and cultural\norganizations of all kinds. No other country in the world can\nclaim such substantial and widespread commitment to\nphilanthropy and volunteerism. But are we, as a society realizing\nthe full fruits of this commitment?\n\nGrant-giving foundations are intermediaries between the\nindividual donors who fund them and the various social\nenterprises that they, in turn, support. But if foundations serve\nonly as passive middlemen, as mere conduits for giving, then they\nfall far short of their potential and of society&#x27;s high expectations.\n\nFoundations can and should lead social progress. They have the\npotential to make more effective use of scarce resources than\neither individual donors or the government. Free from political\npressures,foundations can explore new solutions to social\nproblems with an independence tha t government can never have.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nFoundations Create Value in  Four Ways\n\nOne grant\nX\n\nMultiple grants\n3X-5X\n\nEntire operating budget of one organization\n\n50X-100X\n\nEntire field\n\n&gt;1,000X\n\nmillionsDollar value of resources affected by foundation activity\n\nEach successive approach leverages a foundation&#x27;s\n\nspecial assets more than the preceding one as the pool\no f  \u22ef\n\nV\n\n1. Selecting the Best Grantees.\n\nThe process of value creation here is straightforward. Like\ninvestment advisers in the business world,foundations can use\ntheir expertise to channel resources to their most productive uses\nwithin the social sector by funding organizations that are the\nmost cost effective or that address urgent or overlooked problems.\nFor example,of the many organizations that seek funding for\nprograms aimed at reducing the high school dropout rate, a\nfoundation can select the most effective one.Thus its dollar will\n\nearn a higher social return than a dollar given less knowledgeably\nby an individual donor. In this way, choosing recipients and\nallocating funds is itself a source of value.\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nexpertise to benefit from the increased tourism. The Packard\nFoundation&#x27;s grant paid for marketing consultants who taught\nCEDO how to turn  tourists  into members, creating an ongoing\nrevenue stream for CEDO far greater than the Foundation&#x27;s\n$50,000 grant.\n\nThe Echoing Green Foundation, created by venture capitalist Ed\nCohen,gives $1.4 million a year to improve the performance of the\nnonprofit sector even more broadly. It invests in social\nentrepreneurs, individuals with the drive and vision to catalyze\nsocial change. It aims to build a community of public-service\nleaders who share their experience, knowledge, and energy with\none another. To date, Echoing Green has funded more than 300\nfellows who not only pursue their own projects but also visit with\none another to share best practices. The lessons learned are\nrecorded, distributed to all grantees,and made publicly available.\n\nIn the fall of 1998, for example, the Charles and Helen Schwab\nFamily Foundation in San Mateo, California, joined with the\nPeninsula Community Foundation and the Sobrato Foundation in\na $2 million,two-year initiative to address internal issues of\nmanagement and growth at 16 local family-service agencies.\nEvery eight weeks for the life of the project, foundation staff\nmembers meet with all 16 agency directors. Management experts\nare brought in to address relevant topics. As a result of the group\ndiscussions, three of the grantees have decided that they ca\n\nThe range of ways in which foundations can assist nonprofits goes\nwell beyond making management-development grants.\nFoundations can become fully engaged partners, providing\nadvice, management assistance,access to professional service\nfirms, clout, and a host of other non-cash resources. Improving\nthe  performance of grant recipients often requires foundations to\nwork closely with grantees. It also requires the willingness to\nengage for the long term. Foundations are capable of both.\n\nn\n\n\n\noperate more efficiently if they merge,and foundation staff has\nworked closely with them to accomplish the merger. Because\ntechnology management has surfaced as a major issue, the\nfoundations have researched and funded technology needs at\nseveral of the agencies.\n\n4 .  Advancing the State of Knowledge and Practice.\n\nFoundations can create the greatest value by funding research\nand a systematic progression of projects that produce more\neffective ways to address social problems.At its best, such work\nresults in a new framework that shapes subsequent work in the\nfield-making every dollar spent by philanthropists, government,\nand other organizations more productive.\n\nWithin six years,India doubled its rice production, and Mexico,\nonce an importer of wheat, became an exporter. Nigeria and\nColombia created  their  own research institutes  modeled  on  the\nfoundations&#x27; research.  The Rockefeller Foundation subsequently\ndisseminated its results to organizations from 28 developing\ncountries. Altogether, many millions of the world&#x27;s poorest people\nbenefited from the knowledge created by those two foundations\n\nFoundations are uniquely positioned to study a field in depth.\nThey can set a new agenda and change both public sentiment and\ngovernment policy. The green revolution, for example, had its\nroots in research sponsored jointly by the Ford and Rockefeller\nFoundations in the late 1950s and early 1960s.Concerned with\nworld hunger and population growth, the two foundations\ncreated research institutes that developed new strains of wheat\nand rice tha t doubled and tripled crop output per acre.\n\n.\n\nStudies by the Carnegie Foundation have had a similarly powerful\nimpact on education in the United States over the last 95 years. In\n1904,Carnegie funded research by Abraham Flexner on the state\nof medical education, which revealed a widespread lack of\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\nIn the field of education, the Philanthropic Ventures Foundation\nin Oakland, California, for example, focuses on grassroots\nfunding. In 1995, PVF created the Teacher Resource Grants\nprogram. Working within the large field of education, PVF chose a\nspecialized positioning appropriate to its small size. PVF provides\ninexpensive but badly needed classroom materials to teachers in\nits region\u2014materials that are useless if they don&#x27;t arrive quickly,\nwhen the teacher needs them.\n\nPVF notified more than 6,000 teachers that grants of up to $1,500\nwould be available for classroom materials,field trip s, or teacher\ntraining courses.(After a year of experience, PVF lowered the\nceiling to $500 per grant.) Teachers refer to the program as the\n\u201cfax-grant program\u201d because the foundation takes requests by fax,\nand then sends an answer within one hour of receipt and a check\nwithin 24 hours.\n\nSince its positioning is to help under-resourced teachers and it\nmakes thousands of small grants, the Philanthropic Ventures\nFoundation developed a no-paperwork rule, freeing teachers from\ntime-consuming grant applications.PVF finds that an elaborate\nprocess around  the receipt, investigation, consideration, and\n\nfunding of grant requests is not necessary in its chosen area.\n\nPVF is a perfect example of a foundation that tailored its activities\nto create value. Only by doing things differently from others, in a\nway that is linked tightly to what the foundation seeks to\naccomplish, can it achieve greater impact with the same grant\ndollars or enable its grantees to be more successful. Tailoring\nactivities to strategy is the way a foundation institutionalizes and\nreinforces its distinctive strengths.\n\n\n\n\n\ntyranny of the grant cycle, with barely the time to write up\npending grant requests between board meetings. (See the exhibit\n\u201cResources Are Scattered\u22ef  \u201d)\n\nResources Are Scattered\u22ef\nacross too many fields\u22ef\n\nU.S.Foundations by Asset Size\n\n~520 billion44,000+ asse t size\n100% (in milons)\n\n80\n9S10 -S 50\n\n60\n11551-5250\n\n40\n165251-5999\n\n1551000+20\n\noL gMng 205 10 15foundatlons\nby slze\n\n0\n\nnumber of ftelds funded\n\nThe largest 6% of foundations contributed\napproximately74% of al  grants.\n\nThe data show that resources are spread thin at\nfoundations ofall stzes,but the problem is more\nacute at the smaller foundations.\n\nacross staffs spread too thin\u22efacross too many small grants\n\nResources Are Scattered  . . .  Source: The Foundation  Center, based\n\non a sample of 1,000 foundations giving at least $1 million in 1997\nand excluding grants below $10,000.\n\n.\n\n1 0 5 0 -74 K10=50 549,543\n(52 grants)\n\n35 S60,754\n(81 grants)\n\n551-5250 551-5250\n\n12 5109,3345251-5999 5251-5999 (157 grants)\n51.000+\n\n(397 grants)\n7510004 5222,615\n\n25 50 750 0 75,000 225,000150,000\n\nnumber of grants per employee average grant sze  (excluding those  below 510,000)\n\nSource: The Foundation Center based on a sample of1,000foundations giving at least SI million in 1997 and excluding grants beow 510.000.\n\nThe average foundation,for example, makes grants in ten\nunrelated fields every year,  where fields are such broadly defined\nareas as education and health care. Fewer than 9% of foundations\n\n\n\nmake 75% or more of their grants in a single field, and only 5%\nfocus more than  90% of their grants in one field. Such scattered\ngiving is inconsistent with a clear strategic positioning.\n\nNor do the data suggest that many foundations are taking\nadvantage of their unique ways to create value. Among the largest\nfoundations,with assets in excess of $1 billion,each professional\nemployee handles approximately seven grants per year (and up to\n100 times as many grant requests). There are, on average, just\nthree professional employees for every field in which the\nfoundation makes grants. Staff at the largest foundations may\nwell have sufficient time and expertise to evaluate grants,but it is\nhard to see how even the most dedicated staff could have much\ntime to assist grantees.  The smaller the foundation, the more\nstretched the staff. Among the hundreds of foundations with $50\nmillion to $250 million in assets, there are five times as many\ngrants per professional,and an average of two staff members\nhandle grants in 11 unrelated fields. The smallest foundations\noften rely on the volunteer efforts of trustees, making it almost\ncertain that many decisions are reached with little formal\nevaluation at all.\n\nThose broad metrics also suggest that foundations are not using\nthe more powerful forms of value creation beyond selection.\nFoundations rarely contribute resources other than financial\nsupport. Only 2.2% of foundation grants were designated to\nimprove the grantees&#x27; performance.Ninety-five percent of all\nfoundation grants are for one year.Although one-year grants are\nsometimes awarded for several years in a row, there is little\nevidence that foundations exploit the opportunity to work more\nclosely with grantees over extended periods of time to improve\ntheir performance. Foundations, which should be able to take the\nlong view tend to focus on grant making quarter-to-quarter.\n\n\n\nFinally, while foundations express a strong interest in innovation\nand advancing the state of knowledge about society&#x27;s problems,\nvery few fund studies that  explore the relative effectiveness of\ndifferent approaches to a given problem. Only 8.8% of foundation\ngrants went to research,and most of that was in basic medical and\nscientific areas. Funding studies or data collection is rare, and\nfoundations generally see them as less desirable than current\nsocial services.\n\nInstead of funding research, many foundations seek to promote\ninnovation through seed grants that are designed to establish and\nsupport specific new programs.There is little benefit, however, in\nstarting new initiatives if they do not survive and grow. Too often\nfoundations overlook projects aimed at fostering the growth and\nreplication of new initiatives, or they fail to support the grantee\nover an appropriately long time span. They rarely do the up-front\nresearch and the postevaluation needed to ascertain if their\nprograms have been successful and have continued to thrive after\nthe initial period of seed grant support.\n\nIn some ways, however, the overall failure to evaluate the results\nof foundation grants is the most telling danger sign of all.Almost\nno money is set aside for program evaluation.Many foundations\nare ambivalent about whether funds should be spent on\nevaluation and whether assessing the performance of past grants\ncan improve future grant making. This ambivalence about\nevaluation is reinforced by the performance criteria used to judge\nfoundation staff. These tend to emphasize the paper trail of\npregrant analysis and recommendations and give little credit for\nachieving the real-world results that motivated the grant in the\nfirst place.Program evaluation,therefore, has only a downside:\nfailure risks censure, but success adds no reward.\n\n\n\nThe evaluations that do take place are often problematic in three\nways. First, they are limited to reports as to whether the money\nwas spent as intended (output evaluation);they do not attempt to\nmeasure social impact (outcome evaluation). Second,many of the\nevaluations are done by the grant recipients themselves, who\ninvariably seek further support from the foundation.How\nobjective and reliable are these reports likely to be? Third,even in\nthe few cases where the social impact of a program is measured by\nan outside consultant, it is usually assessed at the single grantee\nlevel,in isolation from the foundation&#x27;s other grants.Therefore, it\ndoes not reflect the foundation&#x27;s success in reaching its overall\ngoals.\n\nCertainly, evaluation may at times be costly and complex.But\ngiven clear goals at the outset, it is always possible. The criteria to\nevaluate a job-training program will differ from those used to\nevaluate a funding program for young artists. But meaningful\ncriteria can be established for both.\n\nConsider the San Francisco-based Roberts Enterprise\nDevelopment Fund,which focuses on creating employment for\nthe homeless and indigent. Working closely with its grantee\nRubicon Programs, REDF developed 25 criteria that not only\nmeasure the success of job-training programs but also help\nRubicon to manage the programs more effectively. In addition to\nthe most obvious criteria\u2014changes in employment stability\nwages,and job skills\u2014REDF and Rubicon found that related\nfactors such as substance abuse and even qualitative factors such\nas the trainees&#x27; own assessments of their success in reaching\npersonal goals were all meaningful measures of outcomes the\nprogram was trying to achieve.\n\nWithout evaluation, a foundation will never know whether or not\nit has been successful. The most basic premise of strategy-\nstriving for superior performance\u2014is violated if performance is\n\n\n\nnot measured.\n\nAddressing the New Agenda\n\nHow can foundations begin down the path we have outlined? A\nnumber of foundations, including those operating under the new\nrubric of venture philanthropy, are already moving in the\ndirection outlined here. But none that we have encountered has\ngone all the way. Putting these elements together into a coherent\nwhole will require developing a strategy, aligning operations with\nthat strategy, and revising the foundation&#x27;s governance so that the\nstrategy can be monitored effectively. Responsibility for such\nchange lies ultimately with the trustees and directors, who are the\nfiduciaries accountable for the use of the foundation&#x27;s (and\nsociety&#x27;s) funds.\n\nTo develop a strategy  the place to start is positioning. This always\nrequires systematic thought and research into important social\nchallenges that are not being addressed well by others. The goal is\nnot necessarily to identify the most important problem,since\nmany are important.W hat matters is how effectively the\nfou nd at ion  can  co n trib u te  to  its  so lu tion .\n\nSecond, a foundation can learn from prior efforts within its\nchosen area of funding. Do current socioeconomic trends favor\none approach over another? What are other organizations doing\nin  th e  fie ld? Can the  work  of th is  foun da tion  re in fo rce  o r\n\ncomplement theirs? Can we uncover root causes of the problem?\n\nThird,what unique strengths will enable this foundation to create\nvalue most effectively in its field? Part of the answer to this\nquestion comes from examining objectively where the foundation\nhas made the greatest impact in the past. It also comes from a\nre alist ic  assessm e n t  o f w eakne sses.\n\n\n\nScale plays an important role in the choice of strategy. A\nfoundation  needs enough  resources to pursue its particular way of\n\ncreating value.Larger foundations may well have the scale to\nwork in more than one field. If they choose to do so, each area\nmust have its own strategy and tailored operations. All\nfoundations, however, can create more value by putting a greater\nproportion of their resources to work.  This means stepping up the\nrate of giving in their chosen fields and investing a portion of\ntheir  investm ent portfolios to support their  philanthropic work.\n\nOnce the foundation has chosen a strategy, it can begin to realign\nits operations.  A foundation, like any enterprise, is a collection of\nmany activities. Each activity-how  proposals are solicited, for\nexample, and how grantees are supported\u2014must be tailored to\nthe chosen strategy  A particularly important aspect of\noperational alignment is the development of measures to help the\nfoundation know whether or not it has been successful.\n\nOperating strategically will require most foundations to rethink\ntheir governance systems. Change will be difficult in an\nenvironment where the pressure of processing grants and getting\nthe money out the door extends beyond the  staff to the\nboardroom. Today boards of all bu t the very  largest foundations\ndiscuss and approve specific grant allocations at th eir meetings.\nWithout goals or strategy, they have no way to delegate the grant\nselection process to staff and no framework through which to\nevaluate their experience.The Chicago-based Crown Foundation,\nin an effort to break this cycle, considers grant requests at only\ntwo of its quarterly board meetings each year; the other two are\nreserved for discussing policy, reviewing performance, and\nstudying issues in more depth. Boards need to move away from\nthe operating function of approving grants to focus on setting\nstrategy and evaluating outcomes.\n\n\n\nWith goals, a strategy, and evaluation mechanisms in place,staff\ncould have greater independence to make grant decisions\nthemselves on a more timely and flexible basis. At the Colorado\nTrust,the board considers and approves multiyear, multimillion-\ndollar initiatives that have clearly defined goals and a clearly\narticulated strategy  Once the board sets the  framework, program\nstaff has the authority to make individual grants for the life of the\ninitiative. Staff members, then, have greater responsibility and\nmore freedom to make decisions on individual grants, and the\nboard  has the tim e to study  the field, set overall strategies, and\nassess staff performance.\n\nFor those who care deeply about social problems and work\ntirelessly to make a difference, current foundation practices not\nonly diminish effectiveness,they inevitably reduce the\nsatisfaction that donors, staff, and trustees derive from their\nwork. Scattered funding, arm&#x27;s-length relationships with\ngrantees, and a lack of awareness of outcomes necessarily create a\ndivide between the foundation and the ultimate results of its\nwork.Acting strategically is much more difficult. But for trustees\nand staff alike, it will be far more rewarding as well.\n\nImproving the performance of philanthropy would enable\nfoundations to have a much greater impact on society.\nFoundations could play a leading role in changing the culture of\nsocial sector management.They could spearhead the evolution of\nphilanthropy from private acts of conscience into a professional\nfield. Until foundations accept their accountability to society and\nmeet their obligation to create value, they exist in a world where\nthey cannot fail.Unfortunately, they also cannot truly succeed.\nA version of this article appeared in the November-December 1999 issue of\nHarvard Business Review.\n\n\n\nMichael E. Porter is the Bishop William\nLawrence University Professor at Harvard\nBusiness School. He has served as an adviser to\ngovernments and campaigns around the world\non the advancement of social policy and\neconomic policy, including Mitt Romney&#x27;s\npresidential campaign.His latest paper is The\nRole of Business in Society He is an academic\nadviser to the Leadership Now Project.\n\nM ark  R. K ram er  is a senior lecturer at Harvard\nBusiness School. He is also a cofounder of the\nsocial impact consulting firm FSG and a\npartner at the impact investing hedge fund at\nCongruence Capital.\n\nRe c o m m e n d e d  Fo r You\n\nBlue Ocean Strategy\n\nWhat Is Strategy  Again?\n\nPODCAST\nCould a New Business Model Make Clinical Drug Trials More Accessible to\nPatien ts?\n\nSeven Surprises for New CEOs\n\n\n", "extra": {"cited_message_idx": 9, "search_result_idx": null, "evidence_text": "source"}, "url": "file-633pKlwcrOvWVr7Ww0esX98g"}}], "gizmo_id": null, "is_complete": true, "message_type": null, "model_slug": "gpt-4", "default_model_slug": "gpt-4", "pad": "AAAAAAAAA", "parent_id": "91aa145a-dae2-43dd-a412-98d19eebb820", "request_id": "8888e7c7890a0e1d-MXP", "timestamp_": "absolute", "content_references": [{"matched_text": "\u30108\u2020source\u3011", "start_idx": 794, "end_idx": 804, "alt": null, "type": "file", "name": "week 4.pdf", "id": "file-0ALsWs9dynkgdtMPP5VuvzmZ", "source": "my_files", "snippet": "\n5/24/24,1:05 AM 12 Common Criticisms of Philanthropy\u2014and Some Answers\n\nStanfordSOCIAL\nINNO VATIONReview\nInforming and inspiring leaders of social change\n\nPhilanthropy&amp; Funding\n\n12 Common Criticisms of Philanthropy\u2014and\nSome Answers\nCritics have argued that charitable giving isn&#x27;t focused enough on the poor, isn&#x27;t sufficient to make a difference,\nis undemocratic, and more, but research\u2014and history\u2014show otherwise.\n\nBy Karl Zinsmeister | May 17, 2016\n\nSince January, I&#x27;ve been traveling around the United States talking to audiences about my new book,\n\nThe  Almanac of American Philanthropy, and how private giving affects our nation. During these\n\nsessions I&#x27;ve collected I2 broad criticisms of charitable action that people sometimes raise. From the\nlessons of my Almanac research,I offer responses below.\n\nI. Charitable aid should focus on the poor; too much giving today goes to other causes!\n\nThis increasingly common argument is supported by the so-called &quot;effective altruism&quot; movement,\nwhich complains that a dollar spent on a university or park or music school could instead have headed\noff a dire problem such as, say, river blindness for an impoverished African.\n\nThe most specious part of this criticism is the suggestion that donors can&#x27;t do both things.\nPhilanthropists are currently producing good results across a vast spectrum of causes, including many\nefforts to help the poor. In fact, the fastest-growing sector of US private philanthropy in recent years has\n\nbeen overseas aid to poor people. Indeed,the poor in foreign countries now get more help from US\n\ndonors ($39 billion per year) than from official US government aid ($3i billion).\n\nAre you enjoying this article? Read more like this, plus SSIR&#x27;s full archive o f  content, when you\nsubscribe.\n\n1/8https://ssir.org/articles/entry/12_common_critcisms_of_philanthropyand_some_answers#\n\n\n\n5/24/24,1:05 AM 12 Common Criticisms of Philanthropy\u2014and Some Answers\n\nMoreover, it&#x27;s shortsighted and often inhumane to suggest that donating to causes other than poverty\nreduction is somehow immoral. Yes,places like MIT and Johns Hopkins are wealthy institutions, but\nvoluntary gifts to them ultimately result in things like portable x-ray machines,new vaccines,and\n\ninexpensive cell phones that are valuable to all people, especially the poor\n\nPart of what makes philanthropy powerful and beautiful is its riotous variety. Allowing donors to follow\ntheir passions has proven, over generations, to be an effective way of inspiring powerful commitments\n\nand getting big results. Cramped definitions of philanthropy that limit donors to approved areas would\nsuffocate many valuable social inventions.\n\n2. Charity is an artifact no longer necessary in a modern welfare state!\n\nSome view private giving and problem-solving as vestiges of simpler times, with which we can now\n\ndispense.  The public,however, disagrees. In a nationally representative survey of likely US voters in\n20I5, respondents chose philanthropy over government as their &quot;first choice for solving a social problem\nin America\u201d\u2014by 47 percent to 32 percent. Asked whether they most trusted entrepreneurial companies,\nnonprofit charities, or government agencies,43 percent of respondents chose charities, 28 percent\nselected entrepreneurial companies, and just I4 percent chose government agencies.\n\nPhilanthropy solves problems differently than government. It tends to be more inventive and\nexperimental, quicker, nimbler, more efficient, more varied, more personalized,more interested in\ntransformation than treatment, and more efficient. The public sees this and values it.\n\n3. Charitable donations are just a drop in the bucket!\n\nAmerica&#x27;s nonprofit sector now commands I percent of our workforce and 6 percent of GDP\u2014not\n\nincluding volunteer time, which,if we attached a reasonable hourly wage to it, nearly equals the $36o\nbillion we donate in cash every year.\n\nThe Gates Foundation alone now  distributes more overseas assistance than  the  entire  Italian\n\ngovernment. It is estimated that in just its first two decades, its overseas vaccine program alone will save\n\nthe lives of 8 million preschool children. Then consider that members of US churches and synagogues\n\n\u2014just one division of America&#x27;s larger philanthropic army\u2014send four and a half times as much money\noverseas to poor people every year as the Gates Foundation does!\n\n2/8https://ssirorg/articles/entry/12_common_criticisms_of_philanthropyand_some_answers#\n\n\n\n5/24/24,1:05 AM 12 Common Criticisms of Philanthropy\u2014and Some Answers\n\nThe fact that most philanthropy takes place out of the public eye\u2014in small doses, and often in private or\n\neven anonymous ways\u2014makes it easy to overlook its size and power. But getting seduced by the\ngiantism of official aid is an egregious mistake. Small actions can and do converge into mighty rivers of\ncumulative effort.\n\n4. There are too many amateur efforts in philanthropy!\n\nIt&#x27;s easy to write off &quot;homemade&quot; solutions as amateurish, but grassroots efforts accomplish many great\nthings. Consider the the ALS Association&#x27;s Ice Bucket Challenge,which raised money for Lou Gehrig&#x27;s\nDisease research.The initiative occasioned snickers and sniping from some professional\n\nphilanthropists, but donations it generated led to a major scientific breakthrough at Johns Hopkins\nUniversity and pre-funding of clinical trials for new therapies.\n\nThere are many more examples. Crusades against autism by Bernie Marcus,against prostate cancer by\nMichael Milken, and against breast cancer by Nancy Brinker were all thought quixotic when they kicked\n\noff, yet each paid huge dividends. The Stowers Institute for Medical Research, the Howard Hughes\nMedical Institute, and Markey fellowships would never have seen the light of day if many professionals\n\nhad had their way. And it was support from the Guggenheim family that allowed physicist Robert\nGoddard to overcome scorn from other scientists and ridicule by the New York Times to become the\n\ngenius of rocketry and father of America&#x27;s success in space.\n\nAmerica&#x27;s strong system of decentralized giving and homegrown problem-solving supports wide\n\nexperimentation and avoids putting all of our eggs in one national basket.\n\n5. Philanthropic aid lacks standardization! It&#x27;s a chaotic patchwork!\n\nThe lesson of the Internet is the accumulated power of millions of small actions. The story of today&#x27;s\n\nhacker culture is that one individual with a laptop can do astonishing things.Small-scale action that\nlacks uniformity should not be considered a failing.It&#x27;s not chaos,it&#x27;s crowdsourcing\u2014hordes of\neveryday people taking lots of small bites at a problem and eventually chewing through even very big\nissues.\n\nThere are rich examples of the power of dispersed decision-making throughout biology and across\nhuman history. Many of our most effective charities discovered the power of decentralization\ngenerations ago. Each of the I,4oo local chapters of Habitat for Humanity, for example,are independent\n\n3/8https://ssir.org/articles/entry/12_common_crticisms_of_philanthropyand_some_answers#\n\n\n\n5/24/24,1:05 AM 12 Common Criticisms of Philanthropy\u2014and Some Answers\n\nentities with their own rules, practices, and funding. All of the 164 regional branches of Goodwill have\ntheir own boards of directors, and are autonomous in policy and funding; the central office is tiny\ncompared to working affiliates in cities like Milwaukee and Houston.And the Appalachian Mountain\nClub efficiently maintains thousands of miles of hiking trails through a network of local branches\n\nThis same principle of accomplishing important tasks through loosely coupled teams or networks of\nindependent actors is also a powerful trend in many of today&#x27;s most successful private businesses. Every\n\nUber city in America has different fares,different products, different practices. Philanthropy can be\nproud of having been a pioneer in solving problems via a flexible ecosystem of participants, rather than\n\nby following standardized formulas.\n\n6. Charity may work for individuals, but what we really need are solutions that benefit entire groups!\n\nAmbitious people may look at the \u201cone soul at a time&quot; model prevalent in philanthropy and conclude\nthat it&#x27;s just too slow. But that perspective misunderstands what social reclamation usually requires. For\n\ntough problems like addiction and recidivism, the most successful solutions rely heavily on one-to-one\nhuman accountability. They take advantage of the useful information available when we actually know\n\nsomeone, instead of dealing with a stranger. By creating personal instead of impersonal transactions, we\n\ncan wield the power of relationships to teach and change behavior.\n\nIt&#x27;s easy to romanticize the &quot;consistency&quot; of government programs, and contrast it favorably to the\ncrazy-quilt of individualized variations in charitable aid, but consistency is not really how humans work.\nIf you have one child who needs a very structured environment and another who blooms when left to\n\nnavigate on her own, you don&#x27;t want one-size-fits-all schools; you want individualized services that\nrecognize and work with intimate differences of personality. You&#x27;ll have a hard time finding that in\ngovernment-run programs, but it&#x27;s a hallmark of philanthropic efforts.\n\nBen Franklin was one of the first donors to argue that philanthropy shouldn&#x27;t just transfer funds in an\n\nattempt to relieve men in their misfortune. It should help build up individuals into a healthier state.\n\nThe goal of charitable aid in the United States has always been individual competence and\n\nindependence\u2014not just social quiet. And this often requires a personal touch, real mentoring, and one-\non-one aid of the sort many philanthropic efforts emphasize.\n\n7. Philanthropy is undemocratic!\n\n4/8https://ssir.org/articles/entry/12_common_crticisms_of_philanthropyand_some_answers#\n\n\n\n5/24/24,1:05 AM 12 Common Criticisms of Philanthropy\u2014and Some Answers\n\nSome critics,especially from the left,complain that donors accumulate too much power and that their\nmoney lets them impose their point of view on society. But it&#x27;s important to note how radically\ndecentralized US giving is. Only I4 percent of total giving today comes from foundations started by the\nwealthy. The vast majority of annual donations come from individuals, dominated by everyday donors\nwho give at a rate of about $2,5oo per household. The very largest single giver in the United States\u2014the\nGates Foundation\u2014grants out about $4 billion per year. Measured against the $36o billion of cash that\nAmericans donate annually, and nearly that much more in the value of volunteered time,Gates\nFoundation commands less than I percent of our annual philanthropy. That is not an unhealthy\n\nconcentration of power.\n\nAmerican philanthropy is also diverse and diffuse. Its millions of givers and hundreds of thousands of\ncharitable organizations compose a kind of huge matrix of private legislatures that define social ills, set\n\ngoals and priorities, and methodically marshal resources to attack problems near at hand\u2014without\nasking the state&#x27;s permission. Admirers of participatory democracy ought to be excited by these mass\n\nactions. As Yale law professor Stephen Carter points out, individuals who give to charity often &quot;measure\n\nthe needs of the community by different calipers than centralized policy makers, and will therefore\ncontribute to a different set of  causes. These millions of individual decisions lead to a diversity in\n\nspending that would be impossible if we adopted the theory that the only money spent for the public\n\ngood is the money spent by the state.&quot; For this reason Carter refers to philanthropy as \u201cdemocracy in\naction.\u201d\n\nAlexis de Tocqueville said in Democracy in America that what impressed him about America&#x27;s voluntary\nactivity was not just the practical problems it solved, but the way the country&#x27;s hyperactive giving and\n\nvolunteering builds up the social muscles needed for a people to be self-governing. Philanthropy is not\njust a sign of self-rule,but also a source  of it\u2014a kind of nursery for broader loyalties to one&#x27;s fellow\n\ncitizens. A healthy democracy should encourage,not discourage,people from acting on their own to\n\nimprove what they judge to be the common good.\n\n8 .  Only government can lead important social change in a fair way!\n\nHistory tells a different story. Private donors and volunteers created the first schools,missions, colleges,\n\nand apprenticeships for Indians and African Americans,often in the face of state resistance.At the\n\nsame time government was enforcing Jim Crow laws,philanthropist Julius Rosenwald erected 4,977\n\nrural schools across America&#x27;s black belt. At the time of his death, 27 percent of all African American\n\nchildren in the United States were educated in one of the schools he built\n\n5/8https://ssir.org/articles/entry/12_common_crticisms_of_philanthropyand_some_answers#\n\n\n\n5/24/24,1:05 AM 12 Common Criticisms of Philanthropy\u2014and Some Answers\n\nThose who view such examples as ancient history and believe that all necessary reforms now flow from\ngovernment are gravely mistaken. According to the UCLA Civil Rights Project, America&#x27;s most\n\nsegregated and often most inadequate government-run schools are all in northern cities with activist\n\ngovernments: Detroit, Milwaukee, New York, Newark, Chicago, and Philadelphia. In fact,the country&#x27;s\n\nmost segregated schools are in New York state, thanks to New York City, where the proportion of\n\nschools in which at least go percent of the students are black or Hispanic rose sharply from 1989 to\n2OIO.\n\nIt is private philanthropy that is shaking up New York City&#x27;s complacent educational establishment\ntoday by launching charter schools. There are currently 95,ooo New York City children in charters,\nnearly all of them minorities and low-income, and another 42,6oo on waiting lists. Stanford researchers\nand other investigators find that these children are receiving significantly better educations than\ncounterparts in conventional government-run schools,in some cases even outscoring comfortable\nsuburban schools in annual testing.\n\n9. Some donors are mean,vainly seek their name on things, or take part in charity for all the wrong\nreasons!\n\nIt&#x27;s true that philanthropists aren&#x27;t always pretty. Prominent donors like J. Paul Getty, Leland Stanford,\nRussell Sage, and John MacArthur were known to exhibit shabby behavior. (Stanford, for example,\n\nemployed stock watering, kickbacks,bribery, and collusion.) Nonetheless, each ultimately managed to\nbe very helpful to others.\n\nThe genius of the philanthropic mechanism is that it accepts people just as they are\u2014kind impulses,\nselfish impulses,confusions and vanities,wishes of all sorts swirling together in the usual human\njumble\u2014and helps them do wondrous things,even when they&#x27;re not saints. Adam Smith taught us that\nfreely conducted commerce can take normal human behaviors\u2014including ugly and mercenary on es -\nand turn them to broadly productive uses.The same is true in the world of philanthropy.Part of the\nmagic of America&#x27;s charitable structure is that it can convert common human impulses into truth,\nuplift, and beauty for all of society.\n\nIo . Philanthropy distracts people who ought to focus on business!\n\nThe right side of the political spectrum sometimes complains that philanthropy drags too many\nproductive business people into do-gooding,distracting them from creating the commercial bounty that\n\n6/8https://ssir.org/articles/entry/12_common_crticisms_of_philanthropyand_some_answers#\n\n\n\n5/24/24,1:05 AM 12 Common Criticisms of Philanthropy\u2014and Some Answers\n\nsociety counts on. But there are reasons to think that philanthropy actually strengthens capitalism.\n\nEconomists Zoltan Acs and Ronnie Phillips have observed that the United States has a distinctive\n\nmeans of \u201creconstituting\u201d wealth via philanthropy.\u201cPhilanthropy is part of the implicit social contract\nthat continuously nurtures and revitalizes economic prosperity,&quot; they write. Researchers Tino and Nima\nSanandaji agree that the \u201clegitimacy of American capitalism has in part been upheld through voluntary\ndonations.&quot; They note that &quot;much of the new wealth created historically has been given back to society.\n\nThis has had several feedback effects on capitalism. For one, the practice has limited the rise of new\ndynasties. Another positive feedback mechanism is that the donations to research and higher education\nhave allowed new generations to become wealthy?\n\nII. Philanthropy encourages collective thinking, collective responsibility, and collective action\u2014\nultimately leading to more government!\n\nThis is another concern sometimes launched from the libertarian right, where observers argue that\n\nwhat American society really needs is more individual responsibility, not more giveaways. However, we\ncan just as plausibly turn that argument around, because there is evidence that philanthropy helps limit\n\ngovernment sprawl\n\nWhen some members of a society become needy, it is a fact that many citizens will insist,&quot;Something\n\nmust be done!&quot; Most times and places,the responsibility for picking up those in trouble has fallen to the\nstate. America&#x27;s energetic voluntary sector, however,allows Americans to meet humanitarian and Judeo-\n\nChristian responsibilities to their fellow humans without setting up large government apparatuses and\n\nregimenting rules that suffocate individual sovereignty\n\nBy solving basic security hungers and stretching multiple safety nets among the general populace,\n\nphilanthropy has made Americans much more tolerant of the creative destruction that&#x27;s part of  a\ndynamic economy, leaving us with a freer and faster-growing economy than comparable industrial\n\nnations. Philanthropy has thus been crucial in allowing America to grow up as an exceedingly rare\nsociety where average people can steer their own lives without the state lurking over their shoulder.\n\nI2. Donating money is sometimes too much about the giver&#x27;s needs!\n\nGiving is a two-way transaction,and the satisfactions of helping are just as real and just as good for\nhuman flourishing as the satisfactions of having someone come to your aid. That&#x27;s why even people\n\n7/8https://ssir.org/articles/entry/12_common_crticisms_of_philanthropyand_some_answers#\n\n\n\n5/24/24,1:05 AM 12 Common Criticisms of Philanthropy\u2014and Some Answers\n\nwith little disposable income are eager to give,and feel good when they do.\n\nSocial science research supports th is.In  a 20o8 paper, three investigators gave study participants\nmoney, and then asked half of them to spend it on themselves, and the other half to give it to some\n\nperson or charity.  Those who donated the money showed a significant uptick in happiness;those who\nspent it on themselves did not\n\nOther academic work has shown that offering aid can actually make the giver healthier\u2014lowering blood\n\npressure, stress, illness,and mortality. Americans who make gifts of money and time are more likely to\n\nprosper and be satisfied with life than non-givers who are demographically identical.  A 20I4 book by\n\ntwo University of Notre Dame researchers concludes, \u201cThe more generous Americans are, the more\n\nhappiness, health,and purpose in life they enjoy. This association \u22ef is strong and highly consistent.\u22ef\nGenerous practices actually create enhanced personal well-being.&quot;\n\nWe shouldn&#x27;t overlook\u2014or discount\u2014the good effects of giving on the giver.\n\nSupport SSIR&#x27;s coverage of cross-sector solutions to global challenges.\n\nHelp us further the reach of innovative ideas. Donate today\n\nRead more stories by Karl Zinsmeister.\n\nKarl Zinsmeister is creator of The Almanac of American Philanthropy, a new encyclopedic reference to the\nfield, just released by The Philanthropy Roundtable.\n\nDOI:1o.48558/jm4I-v703\n\nIf you like this article enough to print it, be sure to subscribe to SSIR!\n\nCopyright @ 2024 Stanford University.\nDesigned by Arsenal, developed by Hop Studios\n\n8/8https://ssir.org/articles/entry/12_common_critcisms_of_philanthropyand_some_answers#\n\n\n", "cloud_doc_url": null}, {"matched_text": "\u30108\u2020source\u3011", "start_idx": 1490, "end_idx": 1500, "alt": null, "type": "file", "name": "week 4.pdf", "id": "file-0ALsWs9dynkgdtMPP5VuvzmZ", "source": "my_files", "snippet": "\n5/24/24,1:05 AM 12 Common Criticisms of Philanthropy\u2014and Some Answers\n\nStanfordSOCIAL\nINNO VATIONReview\nInforming and inspiring leaders of social change\n\nPhilanthropy&amp; Funding\n\n12 Common Criticisms of Philanthropy\u2014and\nSome Answers\nCritics have argued that charitable giving isn&#x27;t focused enough on the poor, isn&#x27;t sufficient to make a difference,\nis undemocratic, and more, but research\u2014and history\u2014show otherwise.\n\nBy Karl Zinsmeister | May 17, 2016\n\nSince January, I&#x27;ve been traveling around the United States talking to audiences about my new book,\n\nThe  Almanac of American Philanthropy, and how private giving affects our nation. During these\n\nsessions I&#x27;ve collected I2 broad criticisms of charitable action that people sometimes raise. From the\nlessons of my Almanac research,I offer responses below.\n\nI.
